The competition principles agreement talks about public benefits and costs in implementing the national competition policy. It is essential that there is consideration of a broad interpretation of public interest. The Public Interest Advocacy Centre propose that the public interest is more than `the balancing of competing collective interests'. They say :
. . . the public interest will vary, but will always include some element of social justice, empowerment and participation in decision-making.

Working for the public interest means challenging the self-defining right of those in positions of power to make decisions on their own behalf or on behalf of narrow constituencies, which will have a negative impact on those at the other end of the power or income spectrum.

In this connection, the recent resolution adopted by all parties in the Queensland parliament is very significant. They called on governments to take greater account of the social impacts of competition policy and to change the public benefit test so that it would:
. . . give full weight to issues including jobs and job security, social welfare and equity considerations, health and safety, and regional development as well as the interests of consumers.
I would add environmental issues to that as well. I foreshadow the Australian Democrats' support for the motion by Senator Margetts in this respect.

The Australian Democrats will use these tests to closely monitor the implementation of competition policy to ensure that the interests of all Australians, particularly low income families, small businesses and those in regional Australia, are properly addressed. Clearly they have not been thus far.

The act before us makes available to the states a pool of $217.2 million in payments to promote competition policy. That is a recognition of progress in this area. The Commonwealth will take into account the advice of the National Competition Council as to whether the states have made sufficient progress in implementing the NCP and the principles laid down in the agreements. That was all agreed at COAG and, even though the Democrats believe that competition policy is yet another ideological attack on the public provision of public services, at least both levels of government agreed to it.

But competition policy has also been inflicted, without agreement and with only the minimum amount of consultation, on the local government sector. Right across Australia, local government is being turned upside down in an effort to come to terms with that. We see local government workers, particularly in my home state of Victoria, losing contracts to private contractors from, in many cases, outside their immediate area. When they lose those contracts, the area loses employment opportunities and money flows out of the community.

Competition policy reform has, for many rural and regional areas, been a very significant force in centralisation too. Local councils are not able to engage in the `buy local' policies and campaigns they might have had previously because that breaches competition policy. As the regulatory review processes crank up, locally determined by-laws will be reviewed, reducing the options available to communities to determine what they think are appropriate rules on, for instance, town planning and community amenities if the National Competition Council regards them as potentially anticompetitive.

In Victoria all councils must put to competition virtually all of their services. Forced competition policy was introduced at a time when local government in Victoria had government appointed administrators and it was used to significantly reduce services and conditions of staff. It also turned out to be a very costly policy to implement in terms of administration and very uneven in terms of delivering cost benefits.

Competition policy will be, and in some states already is, very intrusive into local government democracy and services. Yet, in spite of all that, there is no guarantee that local government will receive any of the payments from the competition policy bonus under this act, because these payments are subject to agreement between just two levels of government and not three, as is so often the case. I think this is a very clear breach of coalition policy before the 1996 election. That policy said:
A coalition government will build an effective partnership between federal, state and local governments based on frequent and high level consultation.
The coalition also promised to recognise the important role of local government in its policy. It said it would:

. . . seek to resolve issues of long-term importance to local government, including the declining share of revenue allocated to local government and the best way local government can participate in the benefits of national competition policy.
It would also:
. . . monitor the impact of the Hilmer reforms on rural communities to ensure that they receive their fair share of the benefits.

Principle 7 of the competition principles agreement signed in 1995 makes it clear that the agreement applies to local government, but it is entirely up to each state government as to how that is achieved. I would argue that, if competition policy is to be seen as a partnership between all levels of government—and it should be—then local government needs to be brought into the loop.

For the benefit of the Senate, the situation at present is that the Victorian state government has promised to local government a share of the competition payments and that these will be delivered to local government at $50 million over five years. But, of course, this is dependent on assessment in council annual reports, a statement of compliance with the Trade Practices Act, achievement of the compulsory competitive tendering target, methods used to achieve competitive neutrality and undertaking of review of local laws for anticompetitive elements.

In Western Australia, local government has secured $5 million over three years at this stage. But there is a shining example; the Queensland state government has made an agreement with the local government association up there and it will give over $150 million over a five-year period. I must say that local government in Queensland, in so many respects, seems to be ahead of the game when compared to other states.

Our policy in this area is very clear. We oppose the use of competition policy to compel local government to tender out its services, as is the case in Victoria. We would also like to see the complete overhaul of our tax system as an opportunity for safeguarding the funding of local government. The financial assistance grants to local government should be restored to real terms per capita levels, as was promised by the federal government back in 1996. We would also generally prefer to untie federal grants to local governments, but encourage Commonwealth-local government agreements for the delivery of national programs and services.

talk.start.para: —I thank the senators for their contributions. I would like to briefly correct a misunderstanding that the national competition policy benchmarks are in any way undemocratic. I think that point was raised in the contributions we have had. These benchmarks are mainly based on the COAG agreements that were already in place when all other jurisdictions agreed to implement national competition policy. Water is a second tranche issue which will be assessed by the National Competition Council in June 1999.

speech.para: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

subdebate.1.para: The bill.

talk.start.para: —I asked the minister if there was the potential for the funding for Queensland to be affected, and the minister has indicated that the funding in this tranche will not be affected by any arrangements that may be entered into in relation to dams. Could he advise the Senate as to whether funding for June 1999 may be affected by the current proposals in Queensland for private arrangements for dams with a public subsidy which may not have gone ahead under ordinary commercial consideration because they were considered non-viable?

speech.para: Could the minister also advise me of the progress of the review of state agreement acts in Western Australia? The last I heard—and it might have changed—they were with the state cabinet and they had been sat on for a long time. I wondered if they had been released. It was one of the issues that was debated between the federal government and the state governments, and it was still suggested that the Western Australian government ought to review its 62 current state agreement acts. Three of them were chosen for indicative review. It has been very difficult to find any information on this, but I wanted to know the status of review of the state agreement acts. Does this relate to the second or third tranche? What tranche does it relate to and what impact will there be on funding for Western Australia?

talk.start.para: —The advice I have received is that the council is currently working on the benchmarks by which these matters will be considered in June 1999. I take it from that that it would be premature to make a comment until those benchmarks are determined. In relation to the Western Australia matter, I have been advised that the same principles apply.

—I am not sure that the minister was quite careful in his listening. I wanted to know what the status of that review is in Western Australia. Has it been released? The National Competition Council has asked for the review of state agreement acts in Western Australia. It is of great interest to a number of people as to whether or not the 62 current state agreement acts or the indicative acts that were looked at are considered to be anticompetitive and therefore have to change in any way in the future. Minister, could you tell me whether that review has been completed or released? This has nothing to do with any of the other agreements; I just want to know whether that agreement has now been released by the state cabinet in Western Australia and when we will have a chance to look at it.

—I have checked with my adviser and the information is that this is a matter between the jurisdiction—that is, Western Australia—and the council. We do not have any advice on that. We could make inquiries on your behalf to see whether we can get that information but, as I said, that information is essentially privy between the jurisdiction and the council.

—This is exactly the level of unaccountability that I have been talking about ever since national competition policy came in during 1995 through legislative change. Here we have Commonwealth taxpayers' money going into paying the states and, in particular, a major issue of contention in relation to national competition policy—state agreement acts. Western Australia is the champion of state agreement acts; we have 62 currently for major corporate welfare. If anything is anti-competitive that would have to be it.

speech.para: It is not in the jurisdiction of this parliament, but the minister tells us it is a private matter between the National Competition Council and the state governments. This is total lack of accountability. The issue was that the National Competition Council was set up by this parliament and this Senate was involved in setting up the timetables. The money is federal taxpayers' money. This minister tells me that whether or not a review has taken place, whether or not it is finished or whether or not we will even see this review is outside the responsibility or the interest of this parliament.

talk.start.para: —The accountability, as I understand it, runs through the Western Australian government. The Western Australian government is accountable to the electors of Western Australia for its actions. I think what the council does is reasonable. It is elected by the Western Australians and it is accountable to the Western Australians for its action. What we do through the NCC is to implement the competition and incentive payments. They are then decided and recommended to the government and the government makes a decision.

—The minister has missed the point. Federal taxpayers' money is being paid for the states implementing the policy which is being reviewed, which is being overseen by the National Competition Council. Federal taxpayers' money is being paid on the basis that the states do what is being asked in terms of implementation. I am not—as you well know—a big fan of national competition policy. I have been one of the greatest critics.

speech.para: If federal taxpayers' money is being paid to the states like Western Australia, have they done what they were required or asked to do by the National Competition Council? Are we paying Western Australia? Were they required to have done this review of state agreement acts by this tranche or the next tranche, or is there any requirement that we should ever need to see this report on state agreement acts? What is the line of accountability if we are spending Commonwealth taxpayers' money?

talk.start.para: —This is a second tranche issue which comes up in June 1999. I have said to you that the Western Australian government is accountable to the Western Australian people for its actions under a variety of areas. Presumably, whether they like and support the Western Australian governments in relation to competition policy will turn the minds of Western Australians.

speech.para: There was an agreement that was signed on by all the jurisdictions on the competition policy. The federal government's role is to provide incentive payments so that states coming together to agree on national competition policy meet certain benchmarks and those recommendations are made. I do not see a lack of accountability there. There is a proper accountability of the Western Australian government to the Western Australians. As I said, we, as a federal government, are providing incentive payments as part of that agreement.
Bill agreed to.
Bill reported without amendment; report adopted.

subdebate.1.para: Bill (on motion by Senator Patterson) read a third time.
Debate resumed from 25 November, on motion by Senator MacGibbon:
That the following Address-in-Reply be agreed to:
MAY IT PLEASE YOUR EXCELLENCY—

We, the Senate of the Commonwealth of Australia in Parliament assembled, desire to express our loyalty to our Most Gracious Sovereign and to thank Your Excellency for the speech which you have been pleased to address to Parliament.

talk.start.para: —I was just about to quote a poem by Banjo Paterson the other day when time caught me out. Just to put it in context, this is Banjo Paterson, one of the great poets in Australian history, talking about the effects of economic theory. He was saying that, when we talk about economics, we should put that in the context where it properly belongs—that is, as a servant of a good community—and that harsh economic theory should not be the thing that dominates the way we go about our business. Matters social, cultural and spiritual should also be taken into account. What he was talking about here was the way a run—a farm in those days—changed its character because of the imposition of harsh economic theory. I think it is worth quoting what he wrote:

speech.para: The owner lives in England now
Of Kiley's Run.
He knows a racehorse from a cow;
But that is all he knows of stock:
His chiefest care is how to dock
Expenses, and he sends from town
To cut the shearers' wages down
On Kiley's Run.
There are no neighbours anywhere
Near Kiley's Run.
The hospitable homes are bare,
The gardens gone; for no pretence
Must hinder cutting down expense:
The homestead that we held so dear
Contains a half-paid overseer
On Kiley's Run.
All life and sport and hope have died
On Kiley's Run.
No longer there the stockmen ride;
For sour-faced boundary riders creep
On mongrel horses after sheep . . .
He goes on in that theme, but I think those words give the sense that Banjo Paterson intended.

The same sorts of things could be said today. I say for the record that the poem appeared in the Bulletin on 20 December 1890, about 108 years ago. The sorts of themes that we talk about now were talked about then. It is unfortunate that the great issues are still to be resolved.

I suppose, as generations go by, the same questions will arise and the answers will be sought. Whether the problem will be solved is another matter. When we look at Australia, we must look beyond simple economic theory—in particular, simple harsh economic theory. Otherwise Australia will go down the path of Kiley's Run.

In further consideration of the speech by His Excellency the Governor-General, which was given in this chamber on 10 November 1998, I mention the heading `Jobs and the workplace'. There is a lack of proper research into how the workplace operates. There is a lack of good investigation in Australia into how the workplace runs: whether it is better off when it is unionised or when it is not unionised or whether there is some other position. That is a trend around the world.

There has been some very interesting work done in the United States of America. I was given an article by Max Ogden, a very emi nent intellect, who works with the Australian Council of Trade Unions. He is a man of great quality. Many a time he has stood with me behind the goalposts when Fitzroy have unfortunately lost more than they have won. But there were great days when we had great encouragement. We stood there for years. Unfortunately, Fitzroy has gone—another sacrifice to forces that operate, not always to the good of the country.

In any event, he referred me to an article which was published in Scientific American, a highly respected journal that deals with issues of science and related issues in America. The work was done by Sandra Black and Lisa Lynch. They put out this working paper No. 6120 for the National Bureau of Economic Research. I have an abstract from it and I think it is worth reading into the record. It says:

Using data from a unique nationally representative sample of businesses, the Educational Quality of the Workforce National Employers Survey (EQW-NES), matched with the Bureau of the Census' Longitudinal Research Database (LRD), we examine the impact of workplace practices, information technology and human capital investments on productivity. We estimate an augmented Cobb Douglas production function with both cross section and panel data covering the period of 1987-1993 using both within and GMM estimators.

I will interpolate there. As you can see, some highly technical processes have been gone through, which are set out in the article. I cannot fully appreciate it. Somebody with your great intellect of course could, Mr Acting Deputy President. All I am pointing out now is that this is work done on the basis not of impressions or anecdotal evidence but very scientific processes. The abstract goes on:
We—
that is, Sandra Black and Lisa Lynch—

find that what is associated with higher productivity is not so much whether or not an employer adopts a particular work practice but rather how that work practice is actually implemented within the establishment. We also find that those unionised establishments that have adopted what have been called new or `transformed' industrial relations practices that promote joint decision making coupled with incentive based compensation have higher productivity than any other similar non-union plants, while those businesses that are unionised but maintain more traditional labor management relations have lower productivity. We also find that the higher the average educational level of production workers or the greater the proportion of non-managerial workers who use computers, the higher is plant productivity.

What they are saying is something that I think my colleague Senator Forshaw, who has vast experience in the union area, would no doubt have known for a long while—that the best way of getting productivity raised is to have high productivity workers in unionised companies. If the union and the company work in a proper relationship, that gives you higher productivity than where you have high productivity workers in non-unionised companies. Of course, where you have the union and the company in conflict, there is not so much productivity at all.

The point that is being made in this article, and that research shows, is that our national policy ought to encourage people to join unions and to encourage unions and employers to work on the basis of an understanding between them. If we get that going, then productivity is going to be higher.

We do not get higher productivity by making workers subject to employment where there is no protection. We do not get higher productivity, for example, through Australian workplace agreements. We get higher productivity by having a good, strong, sensible union in a good, strong, sensible company. I close with that. I think that Australia, and the nation as a whole, ought take on board the need for better economic policy and for a stronger union force.

talk.start.para: —At the outset, I pay tribute to the speech of my eminent friend Senator Cooney, not just because of his eminent status but also because of the content. Indeed, listening to him quoting from Banjo Paterson, I was for a moment transported back to my days at university studying literature. I wish I had more time to read today. As they say, as one book closes another chapter opens.

speech.para: Indeed, we are here responding to the address of the Governor-General, Sir William Deane, given at the opening of this parliament on 10 November. May I, at the outset, also pay tribute to an eminent Australian, Sir William Deane, who is respected and loved by all Australians for his decency, his openness, his tolerance and his commitment to a fair go for all Australians, particularly for those less privileged. Whilst I pay tribute to the man, I have to take issue with a number of the remarks in the speech, a speech which was written for him by the government of the day. The Governor-General, outlining the government's program for the ensuing parliament, at the outset stated:

Above all, the government is committed to implementing the priorities for its second term on the basis of its unequivocal commitment to the Australian values of decency, openness, tolerance and a fair go for all.

I have to say that it is my belief—and I believe it is the view of the vast majority of Australians—that this government pays lip-service to those values and to that commitment. Far from being a decent, open, tolerant and fair go government for all Australians, I would submit that their record of two short years in government has demonstrated to be one of indecency, intolerance, hypocrisy, secretiveness and ignorance of history.

This coalition government obtained a huge majority when it was elected in 1996 at the end of 13 years of Hawke and Keating Labor governments. Yet within a short 2½ years, at the election on 3 October, they suffered the biggest first term reversal in Australian political history. They went from a position of having an overwhelming majority and the confidence of the people expressed in 1996 to a position where they lost 18 seats in the House of Representatives and two Senate seats. Furthermore, one of the six states, Tasmania, no longer has any representatives from the coalition in the House of Representatives.

talk.start.para: —Hear, hear.

—Hear, hear. I congratulate my colleague, Senator Mackay, on her efforts in ensuring—not that they needed much assurance—that the people of Tasmania sent their views back to this government in a resounding manner.
—They'll be sorry.

—The people of Australia are very sorry for what your government has inflicted upon them since they misguidedly or mistakenly gave you a vote of confidence in 1996. They went very close to tipping you out in 1998, and I am confident that they will finish the job at the next election.

speech.para: Let us have a look at what actually happened at the election on 3 October. I want to address some remarks to the supposed mandate that the Prime Minister and the Treasurer—the government—claim for their GST.

The government won the election. They won a majority of seats in the House of Representatives. I acknowledge that. It is a statement of fact. Therefore, they retained government. It is also a fact that they did not get a majority of the votes of the Australian people. Indeed, the Australian Labor Party obtained a majority of the votes on a two-party preferred basis in the House of Representatives. They obtained 51.2 per cent of the votes of the Australian people on a two-party preferred basis—almost four per cent more than the coalition obtained on a two-party preferred basis.

This is not the first time that it has happened in the history of this country that the party that has won or retained government has not obtained a majority of votes. That is the nature of the way in which the votes have been distributed according to the seats. But it is very important because of some remarks that I will quote from the now Prime Minister that he made some years ago.

As I said, firstly, in the House of Representatives the majority of people voted against the government and voted for the ALP on a two-party preferred basis. Secondly and most importantly, in the Senate the majority of voters overwhelmingly supported those parties and those candidates that were specifically and implacably opposed to the introduction of a GST, namely the Australian Labor Party, the Greens and the One Nation Party. Over 50 per cent of people voted for those parties or groups who were specifically opposed to the GST in the campaign. The Democrats had a position which was opposed to the government's GST proposal but nevertheless one whereby they were prepared to consider it. If you add in their vote, 55.8 per cent of people voted for parties that rejected the government's proposed GST.

You can talk all you like about having won a majority of seats and having won government and talk all you like about the supposed mandate theory of politics but the facts of the matter are that there were more people in this country at the last election, just as there were more people in this country in 1993 when the GST was on the agenda that voted against the coalition's proposed GST. They voted against the coalition's proposed tax policy changes. So, when the Prime Minister talks about his mandate and talks about what the people of Australia want, let us remember that the people of Australia, by majority, have voted against a GST.

I would just like to quote, and I am sure that my friends on this side—and, indeed, members of the government—will recall these words. Those opposite do not like remembering them, but I will quote them again. This is what the now Prime Minister had to say back in 1987, following an election where the then Labor government had proposed the introduction of the Australia card as part of its policy. Whilst we retained government, this is what Mr Howard had to say:

By any measure of any politician with any experience, the majority of the Australian people have turned against the identity card. If the Prime Minister and government members doubt our assessment of this, if they really believe that the Australian people have bought their argument about people opposing the card being friends of tax dodgers, why do they not put that belief to a test at a referendum and not hide behind the argument that there is some kind of mandate out of the last election? That suggestion is invalid, not only in terms of the number of votes cast but also on the simple proposition that when people vote in an election, they do not vote on only one issue. The mandate theory of politics from the point of view of proper analysis has always been absolutely phoney. The one thing that would not be phoney would be if this government had the guts to submit this proposal to a referendum.

I would invite the Prime Minister to take up his own words and have the guts to submit the GST proposal to a referendum. It is clear from the last election results, where the GST was a major issue, that a majority of voters rejected the GST, notwithstanding that the government won the election as a result of having a majority of seats.

This Prime Minister, through the Governor-General's speech, talks about openness and commitments to decency and honesty. Of course, the Prime Minister no longer adheres to his views on the mandate theory that he announced in 1987 and he has not followed really any of his pronouncements at all since then.

talk.start.para: —He wasn't too keen on them when he was destroying Whitlam.

—Senator Quirke reminds me of that incident, but I also remind this chamber of a promise that he made not so long ago. Again, holding himself out as honest and decent and committed to these noble principles that we all should follow here in this country and particularly here in this parliament, he said he would not accept the vote of Senator Colston. Look how quickly he changed his position on that after the election. Why has he changed his position on that? For one simple reason: it gives him the opportunity to possibly get his GST legislation—which, as I have said, the majority of people in this country have said they do not want—passed by this Senate before the full results of the 1998 election are represented in this chamber after July next year when the government will have two fewer senators than it has today. He has reversed his position on that, but he still claims this is an open, decent, honest and tolerant government.

speech.para: Let us also look at the way in which the GST was put before the people at the last election. Back in 1993, John Hewson at least had the political honesty and decency to put the proposal before the people well in advance of the election. It was out there and it was debated every day and every night through the media and in this parliament and everywhere else. But what happened on this occasion? Having indicated to the parliament and to the people months beforehand that he was going to bring down a tax package and allow plenty of time for people to debate it and assess it, what happened? The tax package was only released for people to scrutinise after this parliament rose in July. The tax package was released first on 13 August this year. With no opportunity for the parliament to give it any scrutiny, for any of the parliamentary committees to have a look at it or for any proper debate to occur, the Prime Minister, rather than recall parliament, went to his election on 3 October. Just a bare six weeks after this major change in taxation policy in this country was put forward, he called the election.

During the election campaign the Prime Minister said, `We really haven't got all the detail for you at this stage but let us have the election and after the election we will set up an inquiry of some eminent business people to have a look at it.' We did not have the detail; we did not have the legislation. We particularly did not have, because the government refused to put it before the people—even after it was called for by the Labor Party and others—the Treasury analysis of the GST. When that was released after the election, it demonstrated that the GST was going to have a far worse impact upon pensioners, for instance, than had been acknowledged by the government. This was the GST that John Howard said we would never, ever have—another reversal of his position. Yet he says he runs an open, decent and honest government.

One of the most extraordinary arguments that has been put forward in order to suggest that the Senate should simply roll over and rubber stamp the GST has been that put forward by the Treasurer. He argued in an article on 11 November that senators who are currently in the Senate, having been elected in 1993—and will be here until July next year—should vote for the GST that was part of the election in 1998. Peter Costello's argument is that, because Paul Keating said in 1993 that if the people voted for John Hewson and his GST then the Labor senators would not stop it becoming law, that promise made by Paul Keating in 1993 should somehow be binding on senators in 1998, after an election has been held whereby a majority of the people voted against a GST.

The illogicality of the Treasurer's argument is that in 1993, when that promise was made by then Prime Minister Paul Keating, the people rejected the GST and they rejected the coalition. They re-elected the Labor government, with the majority of seats and with the majority of votes. I do not know what has happened to the Treasurer's thinking of late but certainly, if that is the only logic that he can bring to bear and the only argument that he can put forward as to why this Senate should support his GST, then one has to wonder about all of the other arguments that he will be putting forward in support of his tax policy.

I will now turn to one other issue mentioned in the Governor-General's speech—the proposal to hold a referendum on the issue of a republic. I welcome that, just as I welcomed the fact that the people had the chance to elect delegates to the Constitutional Convention earlier this year and that those delegates then participated in the convention. The overwhelming view of the Australian population then was that they supported Australia having an Australian as their head of state. I have often wondered why it is that in the United Kingdom the House of Commons has greater power, particularly with respect to the position of the monarchy and their constitutional arrangements, than we do in our own country.

It is a fact in the United Kingdom that the House of Commons, if they so desired, could vote to change their own constitutional arrangements including—dare I say it—the abolition of the monarchy. They had a go at it in about 1630 with Charles I but later they did not think it was such a good idea. But that is certainly the political and constitutional position. I note that only yesterday Her Majesty, in giving the opening speech in the British parliament, indicated that they will be moving to abolish the automatic right of hereditary peers to sit in the House of Lords. I welcome the day when we will become a republic and follow the example of the British House of Commons. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Hear, hear, Senator. I rise to speak on the address-in-reply, and there are a number of issues that I want to canvass. The first is the appalling performance by this government in the lead-up to the last election, and since, in its management of the people who are unemployed in this country. I refer in particular to the Job Network. I notice the good senator from Victoria over there frowning. She knows as well as anybody what a total—
—I did not frown. I was reading a bill.

—Never mind, Senator. You have invited yourself in as not frowning and therefore not aware. Your good colleague knows very well about it. We have had a Senate inquiry into regional unemployment, which meant the members of the committee traversed and travelled very widely across Australia. Unlike lots of committee inquiries, we took the opportunity to go deep into many parts of regional Australia. The story everywhere was the same: the cuts to government services—to social security, to tax offices, to the Public Service, and not only in Canberra but in particular in regional Australia—have had a devastating effect on these small regional communities.

speech.para: When you add to that the retreat of the banks, the closure of many branch banks, you have a compounding effect. The retreat by government was faster and cut deeper than any previous experience, and that was very devastating. Public sector money was no longer available for spending in the local community. The people who had jobs are no longer participating in community activities, whether that involved the local football club, the netball club, the hospital board or whatever. Communities were suffering dreadfully.

On top of that came very high unemployment. It was bad, but it got worse, dramatically worse, under the Howard coalition government. Senators opposite can remind us of those figures but they are much worse under the Howard government. In the two and a bit years you have been here you have managed to increase youth unemployment considerably—to well over 30 per cent in most of regional Australia.

What did you do? You established a thing called Job Network. What a fiasco! What an unmitigated disaster! At its hearings around Australia, the Senate inquiry heard almost no good news about Job Network. A few people said they were coping, a few people said that they were able to manage, but almost invariably those who were coping were those who had FLEX 3 people, the long-term unemployed, on their books, because they were getting an up-front contribution for that. They were able, therefore, to carry the cost of their FLEX 1 and FLEX 2. For everyone else the Job Network was a disaster.

We all know about Mr Khadar Roude who earned $1 million. He was successful in tendering for $1 million to provide Job Network services in outer Sydney. He turned out not to have a phone, an office, or any facilities at all. He did not last very long in the system.

Then there was Hospitality Horizons, a firm that won a contract for $15 million. I was particularly interested in that contract because, operating out of Sydney, they had responsibility for delivering a lot of those Job Network provisions to the Northern Spencer Gulf region, previously known as the Iron Triangle. Not one Hospitality Network outreach job service was provided in Whyalla, Port Augusta and Port Pirie, the three cities we visited in this region. We have since discovered that Hospitality Horizons has gone the way of a lot of the things that this government has had its finger in. It has gone to no good and to nowhere.

The big problem is that the providers who are left in the system are desperately overworked and receiving very small remuneration for their services. They are going to the wall too. The most decent and proper and hardworking of those people and organisations are now closing down in increasingly large numbers.

Also, many of the employers were vastly annoyed at having to pay up to $250 for assistance and for advertising to get people onto their books where previously the service was provided at no cost at all. In South Australia, some of the employers were furious because it costs $250 per advertisement and in certain parts of South Australia, particularly the Riverland area, much of the work is seasonal. They would be advertising four times a year for the one position, effectively, compared to other people who might advertise once for somebody to hold a job for a year or longer. This is grossly unfair.

There is a rumour that those people do not have to pay. However, it is terribly interesting to know how many people did have to pay and so decided the Job Network was a useless organisation and they would be no part of it. They went back to putting `Job vacant' signs in their windows, and they went back to advertising in the newspapers. No wonder there are increased job ads for those people who count them as a sign of economic recovery. It is because they are no longer getting jobs through Job Network. It is an unmitigated shambles.

I come now to the dreadful treatment of the unemployed people for which this system is designed. It is designed to assist them back into the work force. However, at every opportunity the Job Network has made it hard, if not impossible, for such people.

The first group of people who were upset were those people who were not on any benefit. Suppose somebody, some man or some woman, loses his or her job and they are currently not eligible for any benefit. They are not on single parent benefits, they are not on unemployment benefits, but they have just lost their job, so they go to look for jobs. If they go to the local Job Network, what do they find? They are told, `You are eligible for no assistance at all. We want your name and your number, but we are not going to give you any assistance. You are not on any benefit.' It was very, very unkind and it was very, very inefficient. It was very, very heartless. The unemployed people were the last of your considerations.

When I continue this contribution in the address-in-reply debate I will pick up your recognition that you know it is hopeless. You may frown, Minister, but you know it is hopeless, which is why you are having yet another go at fixing it. Why was it that in the course of the election campaign Senator Kemp's brother, the minister—he may be a great brother but he is a drongo minister—

talk.start.para: —Order! Senators on my right will cease contributing.

—Thank you very much. He may be a great brother but he was a hopeless minister. Even Mr Howard agrees with that, as the minister has lost responsibility for Job Network. He has been demoted, dumped, as they say.
—You can talk!
—Fifty million dollars was found by the government on the eve of the election to patch up the Job Network mess. Aren't you glad you did not get that portfolio, Senator Minchin?

speech.para: Tom Allard in today's Sydney Morning Herald has an article where he says the government itself recognises it must have yet another run at trying to fix this. And the way they wish to fix it? First of all, let us make it even rougher and tougher for the unemployed people. He says:

The unemployed face a cut in their benefits if, after registering, they do not seek assistance almost immediately from Job Network, under reforms to be put to Cabinet by the Federal Government's employment ministers.
I will come back to that again.

I have to say that in the midst of this mess that is Job Network there was the failure of Centrelink to refer any names at all for up to eight weeks in the beginning of the Job Network operation. This government stands condemned on all of those fronts.

The people voted, although they did not quite vote in the right place. You can smile again, Senator Minchin, you are there, but we got the numbers. The people are not convinced and at every opportunity they will tell you that, as you recognise yourself.

talk.start.para: —Order! The time for the debate has concluded.

—My question without notice is to the Special Minister of State, Senator Ellison. Did the Greenfields Foundation furnish the AEC with an annual return under section 305B of the Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918, which requires organisations making gifts totalling $1,500 or more to political parties to furnish a return to the AEC within 20 weeks after the end of the financial year, 17 November 1998?
—Madam President, I raise a point of order. Is there to be a rearrangement of ministerial arrangements in the absence of Senator Vanstone? Could Senator Hill inform the Senate what the situation is?
—I inform the Senate that Senator Vanstone is temporarily absent. In her absence I will take her questions without notice.

—Did the Greenfields Foundation also lodge an annual return as an associated entity under section 314EA of the Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918, which requires associated entities of political parties to furnish a return to the AEC within 16 weeks after the end of the financial year? If not, why not?

—I can advise the Senate that on 31 July this year the AEC received a request for an amendment to the Liberal Party 1996-97 annual return. The amendment identified a receipt by the secretariat of an amount of $4,750,000 from Mr Ronald Walker. The amendment states that Mr Walker advised that the amount is to be a debt assigned to the Greenfields Foundation—a charitable trust. The trustees of the Greenfields Foundation have informed the AEC that the Greenfields Foundation is not an associated entity and that its constitution states that it cannot make donations to a political party. The AEC is continuing inquiries into the matter and I will keep Senator O'Brien posted on that and on the other matters he has raised.
—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Can the minister advise the Senate when it is expected the inquiries will be completed and when the findings will be made public?
—I have no instructions as to when the inquiries will be completed but I will advise the Senate as soon as they are.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts, Senator Alston. Tomorrow's Online Australia Day clearly demonstrates the government's strong commitment to technology as being integral to Australia's future economic prosperity. How will the government's tax reforms help Australia attain maximum social and economic benefit from the new computer age? Is the minister aware of any alternative proposals that might be so backward looking that they could derail Australia's chances of taking advantage of these opportunities?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: —I am delighted to receive a question from probably the most computer literate member of the Senate. Senator O'Chee quite rightly draws attention to the incredible opportunities that confront Australia if we can really take advantage of the information age. There is one thing that ought to be crystal clear and it applies to any sunrise industry, not just this one: the laws of supply and demand operate as iron principles. Clearly, the cheaper the products are the more likely they are to be in demand. The same applies to computer technology. That is why we were particularly concerned to ensure in our fundamental overhaul of the taxation system that a number of items that are currently priced so as to be discouraging for consumers are made much more attractive. You only have to look at computers, printers, keyboards, modems, scanners, digital cameras and a whole range of new age technologies—calculators, telephone answering machines, electric cords, electronic play stations and cartridges and fax machines—to realise that all of these are part and parcel of modern living. They are integral parts of the economic opportunities we have to develop as a nation and to improve our export capacity.

answer.para: The problem is that, up until now, they have been hit by a 22 per cent sales tax courtesy of Labor's 1930s taxation system. When you introduce a GST you abolish all these anti-knowledge taxes and for the first time you make these items much more attractive. You make them fundamentally cheaper. You ensure that Australia has a capacity to attract investment. The tragedy of all this is that the Labor Party knows that that is the way to go but they are not interested in the information age. They could not care less about IT. They do not even have a shadow minister for IT.

talk.start.para: —You are guaranteeing falling hardware costs, are you? Are you guaranteeing retail prices will drop?

—Senator Lundy, I know it must be a source of exquisite concern to you that the big boys would not give you a run in the paddock. I can understand why that is after your performance at Albury. I suppose at least you are allowed out of the change room, which is more than I can say for Senator Schacht.
—Senator Alston, you should not be addressing your remarks directly across the chamber.

—I apologise, Madam President. You have a very stark choice. You have a 1930s tax system espoused by the Labor Party with no interest in IT. They have no shadow minister for IT, which I think says it all. They are not interested in this area of policy. Under us you have a much more outward and forward looking positive approach. What do we see now? Are they interested in the new millennium? Are they interested in Online Australia Day? Of course they are not. They are into the Greenfields Foundation. They are into Mark Textor. They are into anything that moves. The tragedy is that you have a bitter and twisted old man like Senator Ray, who once had the capacity to turn his mind to ideas instead of getting into the gutter. But no, instead of taking the opportunities, instead of learning the big lesson from the election that there are opportunities here and that IT has to be a classic source of them, you would rather sulk in your rooms and paw over all the stuff that the unions send you, all the dirt and filth you can dredge up. As a result you will pay the penalty in three years time.

answer.para: We are looking at a new millennium tax system that will be in such marked contrast to that espoused by our opponents that at least those coming to these shores will not quiver and ask us constantly, `How is it that you were not able to reform the tax system?' Well, we have. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I am pleased to see that we are going to have a new millennium tax system as opposed to a 1930s taxation system. Is the minister aware of any support from leading international information technology countries for the taxation system which he has outlined to the Senate?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: —You only have to look at the drivers of the information economy like the US to understand that the last thing they would ever contemplate is a 22 per cent tax impost—
—They don't have a GST.

—Of course they have indirect taxes at state level, as you well know. The tragedy is that when it comes to taxation systems there are only about three countries that are seriously shoulder to shoulder with this mob over there. They are Swaziland, Ghana and the Solomon Islands. I suppose that is solidarity for you. You take your friends where you can get them, but that won't take you anywhere into the future; that will simply sideline you as a nation. We have had the courage to actually bite the bullet and reform the taxation system in ways that will make the information age a reality in this country. But it is no thanks to the other side of the chamber and it is no thanks to their total absence of any policy initiatives. It is all to do with the fact that you are run by the trade union movement, and the sooner you do something about it the better.

subdebateinfo.title: Goods and Services Tax: Local Government Activities

talk.start.para: —My question without notice is directed to the Minister for Regional Services, Territories and Local Government, Senator Ian Macdonald. Is the minister aware that local government has expressed concern that it is in the dark as to how a GST will affect council activities? In fact, is the minister aware that Logan City Council and the minister's former council, Burdekin Shire, have identified that the GST may apply to up to 50 per cent of their activities and charges? Can the minister clarify for these councils and the Senate whether the GST will apply to the following activities: building approval and inspection, water meter testing, refuse disposal, library membership and book hire for non-residents, district maps and cemeteries?

talker.name: Macdonald, Sen Ian
Senator IAN MACDONALD
talker.role: Regional Services, Territories and Local Government

talk.start.para: —It is a pretty silly question, but I do appreciate Senator Mackay asking it of me. I have to tell the Senate that this is the first time since we have been in government that any senator on that side has asked a question about local government. In fact, the last question asked about local government in this chamber was when Senator Calvert, a former warden of a local authority, asked Senator Bolkus something back in 1995. It shows how interested the Labor Party are in local government. So I am pleased, Senator Mackay, that you have in fact asked this question. I am pleased you have given some recognition to my former council, the Burdekin Shire. I have got to say they are a very good shire. They have gone off a bit since I was on it, I have to tell you, because if I was still on it they would not have asked some of the questions they have asked. They are fairly simple ones.

answer.para: Local government is keen on the GST and the tax reform agenda of this government. In fact, it is quite significant that at the recent Australian Local Government Association forum a motion was put calling upon local government to oppose the GST. It was put by Peter Woods, a nice fellow but an old leftie who was even expelled from the Labor Party. Do you know what happened to that motion at the local government national conference? It was defeated overwhelmingly. In fact, the couple of people who had the temerity to speak to it were almost booed and hissed off the stage. It shows that local government understands—and I do wish the Democrats would understand this as well—that we do need tax reform in Australia.

You would be aware from your attendance at that conference, Senator, which I very pleased that you and I were both able to attend and speak at, that local government, once the truth is explained to them, are very happy about the GST. They now understand that they do not pay GST at all. In fact, they get a huge break. Whilst before they did have wholesale sales tax exemption, there were embedded wholesale sales taxes in everything they bought. Treasury has estimated that about $70 million of wholesale sales tax will go as a result of our program, so rates should be cheaper.

You mentioned councils in Queensland and you mentioned the Burdekin shire council. They use about 400,000 litres of fuel every year, and they are going to have savings of about 25c a litre on most of the fuel they use, because the benefit is for trucks that are over 3.5 tonnes. So there are big savings for the Burdekin council. The Local Government Association of Queensland, which is a very good organisation, have done some work and they have worked out that local authorities in Queensland will save—these are their figures, mind you—some $18 million because of the reduction in the cost of fuel to local authorities. That means big savings for the ratepayers—and big savings for your constituents, Senator. That is why they are very pleased with it.

You have asked about these regulatory matters. I have had conversations with Mr John Campbell, the president, about this very matter. He knows, as you should know, that these are the sorts of things that we will be working through in the next few months and clarifying exactly what is subject to a GST. It is where it is commercial and where commercial operators provide it. That is very clear. Anyone can work that out if they set their mind to it. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. We are attempting to get the truth here and attempting to find out precisely how a GST does apply to local government.
—Don't kid yourself, you're voting against it.
—Order! I ask senators on my right to observe the standing orders.

—I ask the minister to answer the question with regard to whether the GST applies to those very specific instances that I mentioned. Minister, are you aware that it is not just these two councils that are bewildered by the GST but that local government as a whole is completely confused about the application to local government activities? Isn't it a fact that not only you but the entire federal government has literally no idea what the real impact of a GST will be?

talker.name: Macdonald, Sen Ian
Senator IAN MACDONALD
talker.role: Regional Services, Territories and Local Government

talk.start.para: —Senator, you do not understand the GST, but councils do, I am very pleased to say. Watch my lips: councils do not pay the GST. They do not pay it. Even with the matters that you raised, councils do not pay that. Can you understand that? Can you get that through your skull? They know; councils understand this very clearly. If they pay GST, they get it straight back—fully and immediately, with no impact on the councils. But their customers in certain instances, where they run commercial activities, will pay the GST—the same as we all will. It is the customers that will pay, not the councils. If you like, I can give you a private briefing on how the GST works as your lot have not been able to get through to you the impact of the GST. Councils do not pay GST—or at least they pay it, but they get it back, fully and immediately—absolutely, 100 per cent, the same as every business does. You have no idea. This indicates that you have no idea how this works. (Time expired)
—That was a Kemp-like performance.
—It wasn't that bad!
—You were much better, Ian.
—Order! This is supposed to be question time.

—My question is to the Minister for Family and Community Services, Senator Newman. Recently the International Monetary Fund gave a glowing assessment of this government's economic performance and policies. Does the government support the IMF's call for time limits to be placed on unemployment benefits? Has the minister's attention been drawn to the references by the IMF on the need to protect the revenue base from erosion in order to maintain critical community services?

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Family and Community Services; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: —I thank Senator Synon for the question. The government has totally rejected the IMF's recommendation to impose time limits on unemployment benefits. I want to make that absolutely clear from the outset. Australia's approach to welfare is unique in the world. It is a civilised approach—which has largely had bipartisan support over the years—to those who need some form of assistance in our country. However, the government released for the first time last week a public information notice put out by the International Monetary Fund, which is an independent assessment in relation to the Australian economy. The IMF said that its directors welcomed the government's efforts at labour market and social welfare reform. The IMF also said that the directors strongly endorsed the proposed tax reform package.

answer.para: Under our government, overall unemployment dropped to 7.7 per cent last month—the lowest since 1990 and the recession that we had to have, as we were told by Mr Keating—and our skilled vacancies rose by 1.1 per cent in November, continuing the growth trend over the past two years. Skilled vacancies are 18.8 per cent higher than in November 1997, and are at their highest level since January 1990. The number of long-term unemployed recommenced its downward trend in mid-1998, and women's employment has also risen each month in trend terms for each of the last 17 months since June 1997.

I believe that Australia and this government have struck a sensible balance in the provision of social support between two fundamentally important objectives: firstly, the maintenance of appropriate labour market incentives; and, secondly, the provision of an effective social safety net which reflects the Australian characteristics of a fair go for all and decency. Those in this place who care about the provision of social services should embrace tax reform, as that is an important way to stop the erosion of the revenue base which provides the funding for the social safety net, as well as the community services which will be provided into the future by both state and federal governments.

The IMF has also said that the introduction of a broad based tax on goods and services would enhance efficiency while protecting the revenue base from continued erosion. The accompanying reduction in effective marginal income tax rates would improve the incentives for saving and employment. That is what the IMF says. The President of ACOSS, Michael Raper, has said that revenue is the lifeblood of the welfare system in Australia. He also accepts that tax reform is essential for the system's continued maintenance. I agree with Mr Raper, and the Labor opposition should listen very carefully if it wants to have any credibility as a responsible opposition. The IMF endorses our reform package. The government is determined to implement our election promise. I find it incomprehensible that any political party should try to stand in the way of the government implementing its most important election commitment.

subdebateinfo.title: Goods and Services Tax: Transport Industry

talk.start.para: —My question without notice is to Senator Macdonald, the Minister for Regional Services, Territories and Local Government. Can the minister confirm that the costs of the `big trucks' he was talking about yesterday—the trucks that take goods into and out of rural Australia—will fall, as he told us they would yesterday, by 22½ per cent? How will the costs fall by 22½ per cent when the government's own tax reform document states, under the category `Road transport—price effect', that road transport costs will actually increase by 2.6 per cent? Is the minister correct in claiming a 22½ per cent fall in costs, or is the government's own tax package correct in indicating a 2.6 per cent rise?

talker.name: Macdonald, Sen Ian
Senator IAN MACDONALD
talker.role: Regional Services, Territories and Local Government

talk.start.para: —These are the dorothy dixers that my side are supposed to be asking me, but thank you, Senator Hogg, for giving me the opportunity to explain this. I will go through it slowly and very clearly. Trucks currently have a 22 per cent wholesale sales tax on them.
—Which `big' trucks?
—They are trucks over 3.5 tonnes. They are big trucks, Senator Crowley—B-doubles and B-trebles, over 3.5 tonnes.
—Senator Macdonald, your remarks should be addressed through the chair.

—I am sorry, Madam President. I am trying to go through this very clearly, very slowly, for the opposition because they really do not understand it. So I will start with the 22 per cent wholesale sales tax currently on trucks, tyres and spare parts. Under the government's program wholesale sales tax will go, so a truck will be 22 per cent cheaper. But we are going to put a GST of 10 per cent on it. So the truck will have 22 per cent going, 10 per cent added on. But, of course, all of these trucks that run out into the country, all of the trucks that get the goods from the country and take them into the ports, are operated as a business. So, under our plan, all business GST inputs will be refunded fully and immediately. I will just explain that again: 22 per cent on trucks goes as the wholesale sales tax goes; 10 per cent is put on as a GST but, because it is a business input, the 10 per cent comes off. So the net effect is that trucks will be 22 per cent cheaper.
—Big trucks or little trucks?

—Trucks over 3.5 tonnes. Yes, they are big trucks. I am glad you understand that any over 3.5 tonnes are, in fact, big trucks. If they were little trucks, I might tell you—little utes—and used in business, they would get their fuel at 7c a litre cheaper. But getting back to the trucks: do you know how much those trucks are worth, Senator Hogg? Something like $200,000, $300,000 or $400,000. You do the sums; you cut that down by 22 per cent and just see what the cost is.

answer.para: In addition to the wholesale sales tax reduction, in addition to the GST rebated nature of trucks, we can also turn to the fuel. Those trucks, because they are over 3.5 tonnes, get the rebate of 25c a litre on fuel. Fuel is now 43c a litre excised. That goes down to 18c, a saving of 25c a litre. If any of you ever went to the bush, you would understand just how important it is for those of us who live out in the bush to get freight at a reasonable cost. Under your government, the excise went up to 43c a litre. Under our government, for those trucks it is coming down to 18c—huge savings for those of us who live in the bush. That is one of the biggest things we can do for regional Australia, and we are very proud that we are going to do it.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Yesterday, Minister, you told us the cost would fall by 22½ per cent. Today you are telling us 22 per cent. Why the difference? Can you also explain why, in the government's tax package, the cost effect of road transport decreases by 6.7 per cent, yet the price effect of road transport increases by 2.6 per cent? Does this mean that the cost savings made by the road transport industry will not be passed on to consumers, and that rural and regional Australia will actually now face a price increase?
—Ask the Road Transport Forum.

talker.name: Macdonald, Sen Ian
Senator IAN MACDONALD
talker.role: Regional Services, Territories and Local Government

talk.start.para: —I take up my colleague's response: ask the Road Transport Forum and see what they think about it. Go out and ask some of the truckies who operate trucks in regional Australia. See what they think. They have said quite clearly that trucking is such a competitive industry that all of these savings will be passed on to consumers. Those of us who live in the bush—and there are many on this side; regrettably, very few on the other side—know what that is about. We talk to truckies and we understand what huge savings people in regional Australia will make. It is a simple factor. You just have to get out your calculator and work out that it is 22 per cent cheaper not only on the capital cost of the trucks but—and I emphasise this—also on the tyres. Some of those tyres, the big tyres on big trucks, are very expensive, and the cost of those is paid all the time. But it is not the truckies that pay it; those of us who live in the bush have to pay the additional cost of this transport. (Time expired)

subdebateinfo.title: Kakadu National Park: World Heritage Listing

talk.start.para: —My question is addressed to Senator Hill, the Minister for the Environ ment and Heritage. What communication has taken place between the Australian government and the Director-General of UNESCO, Mr Frederico Mayor, regarding the Kakadu field mission report? Has Australia made threats to pull out of UNESCO? Finally, can your government guarantee that Australia will stay in UNESCO if Kakadu is put on the world heritage endangered list?

—I know of no threats that have been made to pull out of UNESCO. As I recall, we wrote to UNESCO expressing our view on the so-called report that has been published by the mission on Kakadu. That was of a similar nature to the letter that we wrote to the head of the mission. I think the letter related to whether it was appropriate that the bureau and committee consideration proceed in the circumstances where the mission failed to honour its commitment to the Australian government that we would receive a draft of the report and have an opportunity to respond to it. The third part of your question concerned any subsequent action affecting our attitude to our relations with UNESCO. I don't think so.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Unfortunately, Minister, it seems that there are some officials in Japan at the moment who are not following your instructions, so can I ask you: can you guarantee that you will give your officials in Kyoto written instructions to cease the threat that Australia might withdraw from UNESCO, and actually provide us with a copy of them by the end of today? I think this is a very important issue. If we have officials in Japan that are not following government instructions, then can we please have written instructions forwarded to them immediately?
—No, I am not planning any further written instructions to our mission.

—My question is addressed to Senator Herron, representing the Minister for Health and Aged Care. Does the minister stand by the government's own modelling which indicates that the net effect of its proposed $1.5 billion private health insurance initiative will be an increase of only 2.7 per cent in private health insurance membership? Can the minister confirm that this translates into around 500,000 new members? If this is the case, can the minister confirm that this means taxpayers will be paying $3,000 for each new member?

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: —I thank Senator West for the question. The question on modelling was answered in the other chamber, but I think it is important that we also put on the record what the Labor Party's position was in this regard. I have some marvellous quotes, Madam President—
—Senator Herron, I do remind you of the question you were asked. Relevance is important.
—Yes. It is just a preamble to the answering of the question, Madam President.

—On a point of order, Madam President: the minister attempts to answer the question by suggesting that the question has been answered elsewhere—you know, as I know, that is not a satisfactory response—and he decides to go and answer some other question that was not asked. I would ask you to direct the minister to answer the question that Senator West directed to him. That is what he is obligated to do, and I think you are obligated to ensure that he conforms to standing orders.
—I have reminded Senator Herron of the question that he has been asked, and relevance is important to the answer.
—Thank you, Madam President.
—You can't answer it, can you?

—I am very happy to answer it. Senator Faulkner is doing his usual bit of grandstanding. There were modellings done, of course, because we were faced with the position when the Labor Party was in government of a fall-out in private health insurance from 70 per cent to 35 per cent. What I was going to put on the record was a statement by the then health minister just before we came into government. She said in a second reading speech on 2 February 1995, and I think it is important we record it:

answer.para: The reforms—
that is, her reforms—
will place the health insurance industry in a position to achieve efficiency gains and pass on the benefit of these gains to their members in the form of lower premiums and better controlled costs.

And what happened after that? In the little over 12 months before we took over government, private health insurance fell by 2½ per cent. So it fell more rapidly. That was the Labor Party's approach.We unashamedly support private health insurance. The Labor Party has taken a totally different tack on this since we came into government. Many of us who were here well remember the then health minister, Graham Richardson, saying—

talk.start.para: —And still says.
—And still says. Thank you, Senator Patterson. I quote from the Age of 25 July 1993:

answer.para: At a bare minimum we must try to stop the decline in private insurance. If the coverage gets any worse we will have huge problems with the queues in public hospitals.

Madam President, what has happened to the Labor Party? Why aren't they advocating private health insurance? That is the only way we can solve the situation that is existing now where wealthy people are excluding people from public hospitals because they have dropped out of private health insurance.

talk.start.para: —If I could take a point of order, Madam President: the minister has had now a considerable amount of time to answer the question. He was asked about the government's modelling only resulting in a 2.7 per cent increase in private health membership. That has not been canvassed. He was asked whether that translated to around, I believe, half a million new members—which he has not attempted to address—and whether that meant taxpayers would be paying $3,000 for each new member. That was the question, and he ought to be directed to answer it.
—He may not have answered as you want, Senator Faulkner, but you could not say that the answer being given is not relevant to that question.

—It is obvious that the Labor Party has no understanding whatsoever of the problems of health care in this country. I will give an example to answer specifically the question Senator West asked. They have assumed that a percentage will increase without taking into account the tax deductibility, for example, that will occur for 80 per cent of people who would be insured under our proposals and have virtual tax deductibility of their insurance premiums. They also do not take into account the fact that the fall-out of privately insured people means that they must be accommodated in public hospitals. There is no other alternative. Have they got another alternative?

answer.para: The Labor Party is still a policy free zone in relation to health care. They have no answers whatsoever. They were in government for 13 years, and what occurred over the 13 years that they were in government was a free fall in private health insurance. We are attempting to slow that down. I cannot remember whether it was Senator West or another senator asked me a question earlier this year when I said it would plateau. Private health insurance has been plateaued in Queensland for 14 years. It has just now dropped below 30 per cent. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Is the minister aware that the Productivity Commission found that each person who transferred from public to private treatment led to a saving of just $252, and how does the minister justify spending $3,000 per new member to save $252?

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: —Senator West has missed the point that I made previously. She is only taking into account new members and not those who are being retained in private health insurance. That is the whole objective—to retain people. Under the present arrangements they are dropping out because they cannot afford it. We are putting a floor under private health insurance so it can be sustained. Again, nobody takes into account the fact that nearly 14 per cent of people who go to private hospitals are self-insured, particularly for one-day stays. It has not got through to the Labor Party that this is in fact what occurs in the real world. There is cross-subsidisation between the specialists in the public hospitals and the specialists in the private hospitals. Because nobody on that side has ever worked in this sort of situation, or it is so long ago they do not know what is occurring at the moment, they have no understanding of the health system of this country. They demonstrated that when they were in government. (Time expired)

subdebateinfo.title: Forestry: New South Wales and Tasmania

talk.start.para: —My question is to the Minister for the Environment and Heritage. To what degree will the growing furore over the Carr government's failure to protect hundreds of thousands of hectares of wild forest in New South Wales damage the image of the Sydney Games as the `green' Olympics? Added to that, is the minister aware that Australia's and the world's most lofty hardwood tree, a Eucalyptus regnans in the Styx Valley near Hobart, has essentially been left unprotected in a sea of loggable forest under your Tasmanian regional forest agreement? I further ask: is the road currently being bulldozed along the wild Huon River in Tasmania not the same one which the minister's departmental officials back in 1993 warned was going to damage world heritage values in Tasmania? Is it not likely, therefore, with this logging activity in Tasmania, that you will see a repeat of a world heritage mission condemning that activity in Tasmania and placing the world heritage Tasmanian wilderness on the list of threatened world heritage properties?

—I am staggered to learn that Senator Brown and I hold a common position in relation to the Carr government's contribution to the RFAs. We both oppose the position of the Carr government because that government has unilaterally undermined the RFA process which is, of course, designed to provide world-class conservation reserves together with sustainable, productive forests harvested according to best forestry management practices. The Carr government has, however, breached the agreement and unilaterally gone out and taken short-term choices which it believes to be to its electoral advantage prior to the New South Wales election in March. That is shortsighted, it is not going to result in a good conservation outcome, and it is not going to result in the maintenance of forestry jobs based on a sustainable forestry industry—jobs for this generation and jobs for future generations. So, yes, Senator Brown, we join with you in condemning the Carr government. It has failed its people in New South Wales in this instance.

answer.para: In relation to Tasmania, I am pleased to see that in Tasmania we have achieved the goal of good conservation outcomes and good forestry outcomes through a negotiated agreement between the Commonwealth and the Tasmanian state government. It is interesting how widely that agreement has been accepted. Apart from Senator Brown and the last merry men that he retains—which is not too many these days—most Tasmanians will see that what was achieved was a fair and sensible outcome that will preserve Australian jobs and, at the same time, preserve a very fine conservation reserve system. If there is some threat to that conservation reserve, then certainly we will investigate it and, if it threatens world heritage values, we would take the action that is necessary to protect those values.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question of the smart alec minister.
—Senator, that is an appropriate way to address the senator. I would ask you to rephrase your question.
—Madam President, the minister might smile and feel smarmy about it, but while he is doing it world heritage value forests in the Tasmanian wilderness are being logged.
—Order! I cannot hear what is being said in the chamber. Order!

interjection.para: Government senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —I will not! I ask the minister: will he withdraw his chainsaws and bulldozers from world heritage value forests in Tasmania?
—Senators on my right will cease shouting.

interjection.para: Honourable senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —I asked the senator to rephrase his question, which he did.

—Madam President, on a point of order: Senator Brown referred to the Leader of the Government in the Senate by a term which is clearly unparliamentary and, rather than just asking him to rephrase the question, he ought be asked to withdraw.
—I regard asking him to rephrase his question as the same as asking him to withdraw, and he has rephrased his question. The word is withdrawn in that sense.

—The question specifically to the minister is: why has the tallest hardwood tree on the face of the planet been left unprotected by any official reserve? Has the minister been to visit this tree? Is he aware that by his actions forests right around that tree are threatened by logging? What action will he take, firstly to visit the tree and secondly to protect this world heritage value forest?

—I am not sure whether I have visited that particular tree but I have certainly visited some very fine forests in Tasmania, and I am very proud of the fact that those forests are being properly protected. I presume Senator Brown is referring to forests that have been set aside for sustainable harvesting, which is part of the balance that was negotiated between the Commonwealth and the state pursuant to a framework that was, I have to concede, negotiated by the previous ALP government.
