That report is now being implemented under the proper and appropriate chairmanship of former senator Bob Collins, who has a job looking after interests in that area. That report says at page 9:
Traditional ownership is not a static construct and such issues can be, and are, fiercely contested in a region like Kakadu that has been depopulated and repopulated.
It also says:
There is no ready means to return to some pristine pre-uranium mining, pre-national park regional state that is independent of government.

I also turn to a report of a committee that you chaired, Mr Acting Deputy President Chapman, the report of the Senate Select Committee on Uranium Mining and Milling that was tabled in this place in May 1997. This is the document we should be debating—not some document prepared by a mob of international tourists who flitted into the place with preconceived concepts and did not spend the time that your committee did, Mr Acting Deputy President. That important report is totally owned by and signed off by Senator Mark Bishop and Senator Margaret Reynolds of the Labor Party. I quote from it:
The hazards of mining and milling uranium, if those activities are properly regulated and controlled, are not such as to justify a decision not to develop Australian uranium mines.

The Senate select committee found that the principal findings of the Ranger uranium environmental inquiry, the Fox report, re mained valid as the foundation for policy on mining of uranium. I quote from page 35 of that report:
The ERA mine at Ranger is widely regarded as the most regulated mine in the world. This observation is especially true of supervision and monitoring of Ranger's impacts on the environment.

Sure, there is an impact of uranium mining on Aboriginal communities but employment is important. It certainly is one of the impacts. There are also issues relating to parks and tourism. Also, the draft environmental impact statement indicates the number of people who are looking at this area.

The Territory ALP's position on uranium has been well documented. Senator Bob Collins is on the record in this place as having recognised the reality of uranium mining in the Territory. Mr Jonathan Nadji in a letter to Senator Hill has expressed his extreme disappointment.

This whole issue of Aboriginal consent is vital. In 1982 and 1991 the people approved it. The next generation have now walked away from that. We cannot have this sort of inconsistent decision making. It is time the Mirrar people took seriously their obligation to use uranium resources to contribute to their own economic and social welfare—and also recognised their privileged right to contribute to other Aboriginal needs and to the wider Northern Territory community. It was their elder statesmen and generation, the parents and grandparents of Yvonne Margarula, who made these decisions, and the cultural values are not just a moving feast to be played with by the Democrats and the Labor Party. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I agree with Senator Allison that the government has failed to manage its World Heritage areas properly, to manage the heirlooms and icons of this nation—the creme de la creme of the natural and cultural areas that this nation, together with the rest of the world, has placed on the World Heritage list, not only for the celebration of the world communities in our time but for the celebration of all future generations. That is so often forgotten in a close-up knockabout debate about such things as mining when it is undertaken in the way that the government has done.

speech.para: What is really at the centre of this debate this afternoon is the reprehensible behaviour of the minister `for the environment'. That is his title, in this government. Never before in all the history of people occupying that office has any minister not only disregarded his responsibility but time and time again gone against that responsibility to argue against the interests of the environment that he is supposed to be serving. That is why I would agree with the honourable Leader of the Opposition, Mr Kim Beazley, when he said in public that this is the worst performing environment minister this country has ever seen. The litany is very long. It goes through greenhouse gases to the protection of World Heritage properties to the awesome destruction by the logging industry which he has been the purveyor of in his years as minister.

The current situation in New South Wales, where hundreds of thousands of high conservation value forests are going to be fed to the chainsaws by the Carr government, is compounded when you hear this minister for the environment stand in this chamber this afternoon and say, `That is not enough. I would feed more into the chainsaws.' I have here photographs of the trip the minister for the environment referred to, when he went to the Tasmanian World Heritage area vicinity after assuming the mantle of minister. Here he is, standing in a clear-felled area of World Heritage value forests—although they are not within the World Heritage area—looking at what is going on around him. Since he has been to those forests, he has personally sounded the death knell for the destruction of the very forests he was looking at, World Heritage value forests. Once again he has done this against the advice of his own department and against the advice of world authorities on those forests.

When it comes to Kakadu, the best he and Senator Tambling can do this afternoon is try to emphasise the difference of opinion that can be found within the indigenous community in this country, which is no less valid, I guess, than the difference of opinion that can be found within the wider community. Sena tor Tambling began his contribution by referring to a motion which is naturally, by force of numbers, going to be passed in the Northern Territory assembly today. He said that this is where the real opinion should be. I submit that he is wrong. If he wants to bring it down to the fine point, the real arbiters of this decision ought to be the traditional owners, the Mirrar people, who are rock solid 100 per cent against this destructive mine being built in the Jabiluka valley under the auspices of this minister for the environment, who goes against the very name of his ministry.

Those people are now being represented at this all-important World Heritage committee meeting in Kyoto. I do not know what the outcome of that will be but I do know this: this minister will be leading a political onslaught against the top environmental and World Heritage advice in the world which says that this mine, quite clearly, is a danger to the cultural and natural values of that magnificent Jabiluka valley. What a disgrace this minister is. What a disgrace this government is. What a reprehensible way to be letting down the environmental values which his office ought to be upholding, which this government ought to be upholding, not only on behalf of the Mirrar people and this nation but on behalf of the whole planet and all future generations. I totally support the motion.

talk.start.para: —I do not totally support the motion. I think this motion completely misrepresents the government's position on this matter and the general issue of World Heritage listing. The real central issue of this is whether the indigenous people of the area have really suffered any loss or have gained any benefit from uranium mining at Ranger and the proposed mine at Jabiluka. Let us have a look at that. First of all, uranium mining in the Kakadu region has provided substantial benefits to Aboriginal people in the area for more than 18 years.
—Ninety per cent of children in Jabiluka have scabies.

—I doubt very much whether that is anything to do with uranium mining. It is more a public health issue. While you may seek to tie scabies and all sorts of other things into the possible undesirable side-effects of uranium mining, I do not think that would really stand up to any sort of serious examination.

speech.para: The government has sought to maximise opportunities for traditional owners and other people in the Kakadu region in relation to mining in Jabiluka through a sound statutory network which provides mechanisms for representation, statutory royalty equivalents and negotiated benefits. Since the Ranger mine began back in 1981, a total of $48.2 million in benefits have flowed to the traditional owners. That is a lot of money and it has been of great benefit to that Aboriginal group.

The money that has gone through to the Aboriginal community has been made up of $1.3 million in up-front payments, $3.4 million from rental payments and $43.5 million in royalty equivalent payments. That, as I said, has amounted to $48.2 million. The proposed Jabiluka mine, which has not yet commenced operation, has already generated $3.7 million in benefits for Aboriginal people under the 1982 Pancontinental agreement.

These include $1 million in July 1982 distributed by the Northern Land Council. The Djabulukgu Association, which I think is the local Aboriginal group, received 80 per cent of that while the Gagudju Association received 10 per cent and the Kunwinjku Trading Association, which is now known as the Narbalek Traditional Owners Aboriginal Corporation, got 10 per cent. Eight hundred thousand dollars, comprising four annual payments of $200,000, went to the Northern Land Council for its administrative costs. Senator Allison, I think even you would agree that is a useful benefit to the entire Aboriginal community of the Northern Territory. A total of $1.2 million on commencement of construction is to be distributed by the Northern Land Council in the same proportions as in 1982. These funds are all held by the Northern Land Council.

Under the 1998 deed poll, there is $0.1 million on commencement of construction for NLC administrative costs; $0.25 million on commencement of construction for a women's resource centre is to be distributed at the direction of the Bininj Working Committee; $0.315 million on commencement of construction will be used for social impact monitoring; and $0.7 million on commencement of construction will be used for the control of alcohol.

Alcohol, drugs and glue sniffing are the serious problems which the Aboriginal communities in the north of Australia face. If Aboriginal communities can receive royalties from mining and minerals, which are under the ground already and over which they have walked for millions of years without any adverse effect, then I am all in favour of this for the benefit that it brings. These figures do not include various ad hoc payments to Aboriginal interests. Over its life, the Jabiluka mine will provide a further $210 million to Aboriginal interests. It is expected that these funds will be used to complement government programs and provide additional benefits in the areas of housing, community based education, cultural heritage and land management programs, development of a regional Aboriginal languages interpreting service—(Time expired)
Question put:
That the motion (Senator Allison's ) be agreed to.

division.result.para: Question so resolved in the negative.

talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para: That the Senate views, with deep concern:

(a) the Federal Government's callous disregard and total lack of interest in ensuring that the community has access to both affordable and accessible banking services, as evidenced by the fact that under the Howard Government over 484 bank branches were closed in 1997-98; and
(b) the failure of the Government to:
(i) formally monitor bank fees, and
(ii) rule out a goods and services tax being applied to bank service charges.

I would like to set the scene for this debate by reflecting on the state of Australia's banking sector—the big four: the Commonwealth, NAB, ANZ and Westpac. Collectively, they have just announced profits of $5.6 billion for this year. Over the 1990s, a period with low inflation and modest economic growth, these four banks have increased their profits by almost 440 per cent. The profit of these banks has increased by almost 440 per cent over the 1990s. To put this in perspective, the big bank profits have grown 3½ times faster than the economy as a whole. No other industry, no other sector, has been able to do as well or even come close to the banks in the last 10 years. This has been driven largely by the retail side of their activities.

Each bank is currently earning a 20 per cent-plus return on its capital for its shareholders. It is unheard of to have a sustained 20 per cent on retail. Mums and dads, ordinary Australians, have seen their banks charging them and closing their branches. It is in the retail area that the banks have been really making their profits. A 20 per cent return on shareholders' funds in low inflationary times is a historic sustained high for banks. These levels have come from massive increases in the volume of home lending, despite the margins having fallen from mortgage originators providing direct competition. I will return to this point later because it is very important.

The banks have also been able to achieve this level of returns on their retail sector. The accounts of the banks published in the last few weeks have made this clear. In 1997, the big four banks earned $3.2 billion more from fees and charges than at the start of the decade. That was a massive increase in their non-traditional income. The big four, before abnormals, increased their profits this year by seven per cent. The NAB in particular increased its profits by 13 per cent.

What lies ahead for the sector? One analyst was quoted in the Financial Review recently as saying that margin pressures are abating and the threat of mortgage originators has been contained. This should send a shiver down the spine of all Australians. Banks are starting to say, `We've got the mortgage originators, Aussie Home Loans and all the people like that covered now. It has been a bit of a bulge, but we have got them covered.' This is very worrying. APRA, the new regulator for banks, has warned that banks' overall margins are going to be squeezed as the Asian crisis works its way through the economy, meaning reduced profits. So APRA is warning that the economic circumstances mean banks are not going to be able to grow in the way they have.

Others are not so pessimistic, however. There are people in the markets who are forecasting average earnings per share growth of 10 per cent for banks, despite the contrac tion in the Australian economy—on the government's own forecasts, on the market's forecasts—dropping down to anywhere between two and 2½ per cent. What we are going to see is the economy starting to slow down. That is universally agreed. There is debate about how much. But what we are going to see is banks still maintaining, on average, across all their sectors—not just their retail sector—a level of 10 per cent.

Cost cutting has been a part of the equation, but some believe that there is not much fat left. How in the absence of the easy cost cutting will banks keep delivering to their shareholders who have been enjoying a five-year bull-run of almost constantly rising share prices? A recent report by Rahoul Chowdry from Price Waterhouse Coopers pointed out that about $1.3 billion from banks' interest income has gone, because of the home loan originators. One point three billion has gone from banks' margins—

talk.start.para: —Who wrote that speech?

—Are you allowed to speak in this debate? You have been dumped from this portfolio area. If I were you, I would sit there and be quiet. Your government has decided exactly what it thinks of you and your performance. You have been dumped from the treasury area. You have now been shoved off somewhere else. I would sit there and be quiet, if I were you. Rahoul Chowdry stated:

speech.para: Growth in income from non-interest income related sources and efficiency gains will be priorities.
We are likely to see further staff layoffs and cost savings from centralisation of services, out-sourcing and from restructuring plans undertaken recently.
NAB has been the biggest fee hiker with an `impression' 35.9 per cent rise in its non-interest income from $2.9 billion to $3.9 billion.
This was a 77 per cent increase in fees and commissions.

That is why NAB are doing so well; that is why they are top of the tree. They are gouging their customers, their retail customers, their mums and dads, bigger and better than anybody else. But they are not alone. The Commonwealth reported a 23.7 per cent, or $361 million increase in its fees. Westpac had an increase of a mere 15.2 per cent, equating to $264 million. That is what banks have been doing over the last 12 months with fees and charges and the benefits they are getting. What has the NAB to say in the light of this? Mr Hadyn Park, their spokesperson, said there was no link between the bank's profits and branch closures. He said increases in fees were unavoidable as lending margins were squeezed by low interest rates and free services could no longer be subsidised by interest earnings. Compare this with the comments of Mr Hockey, the Minister for Financial Services and Regulation, in the other place on 24 November 1998—earlier this week. He said:
There is a simple choice here: do you want lower interest rates, do you want competition in the provision of financial services—
It is funny but I always thought interest rates were driven by inflationary expectations and other factors. The margins are meant to be driven by competition. Mr Hockey went on to say:
The trade-off has been that people are starting to pay for some of the services that they are demanding of the bank—

That is right—demanding of the bank. Pensioners are demanding to be able to walk into their bank and take their money out using a teller, and now they are being forced to pay. It is an absolutely unbelievable statement by the minister. But I guess the ultimate insult in the minister's speech came at the end, and this sums up the government's view. The minister, Mr Hockey, said:
. . . we have the opportunity to get the full benefit of user pays.

The full benefit! I am not sure how much more of the full benefit battling Australians can afford to get under this government. The government has recently introduced the brave new world of Wallis, something which the opposition supported in principle, as Senator Campbell knows, but we did raise some concerns over some of the issues in this area. Senator Campbell and I both spoke on it at the time the bill was being debated. What were the views of its author?

talk.start.para: —Before I got dumped.
—Before you got dumped, that is right, Senator Campbell, dumped from your portfolio where you really wanted to be. What were the views of its author, Mr Wallis? He said:

speech.para: I think, at the end of the day, it does come back to the Government. If it's going to be part of the social welfare fabric of this country then it has to be recognised as (such).
Earlier, Mr Wallis told journalists that cross-subsidisation would disappear as other areas of banking became more competitive, delivering overwhelming consumer benefits. He said:
The overriding consideration (of the inquiry) is clearly to deliver the consumer a better deal.

So Mr Wallis, the Wallis inquiry and the report that he brings down, say that the overriding consideration of the inquiry is to deliver the consumer a better deal. What was the view of Mr Costello when he introduced the government's response to the Wallis report on 2 September 1997? He said:

The measures I have announced today will facilitate greater choice and competition in financial services. They will encourage more rapid innovation, providing wider access and enhanced levels of service. Australia will have a world class regulatory structure that ensures the highest standards of prudence and safety and consumer protection. Regulation will be more efficient, with greater consistency and less overlap. More openly contested markets will drive lower industry costs and prices.

To drive lower industry costs and prices is the aim. That is what this government says it wants to come out of its regulation and what it wants to achieve for ordinary Australians. Mr Costello was asked a question on 20 June 1996. He replied:

May I say in relation to fees as well, this government takes the view that red-hot competition is the best way of having continual surveillance of financial institutions on each other in relation to fees, just as it is the first and best port of call in relation to interest rates.
Red-hot competition. What has been the result of the red-hot competition?

talk.start.para: —Lower interest rates.

—I will come to lower interest rates, Senator Tierney, don't you worry about that. What has been the result of this red-hot competition? The National Bank has led the changes, increasing its minimum balance applicable to fee-free transaction accounts from $500 to $1,000. The bank has also introduced a charge for customers failing to pay minimum monthly balance on credit cards within 30 days of the due date.

speech.para: The ANZ Banking Corporation will raise its monthly account keeping fees from $4 to $6, introduce a $15 charge on lost cards and raise the cost of stopping cheques from $7.50 to $15. It has also introduced a $6 monthly fee on pensioner deeming accounts for balances below $500, all to come into effect on 18 January.

Westpac raised its annual fee on selected credit cards from $18 to $24 and is introducing a fee for overseas foreign currency purchases or cash advances by credit card, effective from 1 January. St George has already implemented similar types of things. From 1 December, as we saw last week, the cost of over the counter withdrawals at a Commonwealth Bank branch will go up from $1.50 to $2 and a fee on a cash withdrawal from an automatic teller machine, an ATM, will jump from 45c to 60c. But red-hot competition will have further benefits for battlers. Industry experts are predicting the changes by the Commonwealth Bank last week will trigger a new round of fees and charges, increasing over the next six months.

A recent study by Marketfaxts of transaction account charges reveals that almost all fees levied by the major banks increased, and in some cases doubled, in the past year. Is it any wonder that the recently established Financial Services Consumer Policy Centre will investigate anti-competitive and unfair fees and charges, in particular the question of whether there is any collusion on fees. How much more of the benefits of red-hot competition can battlers take under this government? I would like to now turn to the issue of branch closures and the impact on the community. Banks are more than just a financial institution, they form the core of a community, particularly rural communities. Many small shopping centres depend on the proximity of a bank. It is obvious that you shop where you bank. If you close the bank, the shoppers will move and your shopping centres are going to die.

A recent study by the University of Queensland concluded that when the last branch in an area is closed, 90 per cent of respondents are more pessimistic about the future of their community and 39 per cent say they would like to leave the town as well. That is the direct impact. This has been recognised by ANZ recently which announced they have allocated $10 million to support community banking initiatives in both rural and metropolitan areas. This has been partly in response to the outcry and partially due to Bendigo Bank's establishment of community branches and its criticism of the behaviour of the big four. The jury is out on ANZ but it is a welcome move and I wish them success.

A recent survey of Sydney's branch network revealed some startling findings. More than 100 Sydney suburbs or localities have been left with reduced services or no branch. In the past three years—since the end of 1995—138 branches have closed in Sydney.

talk.start.para: —Tell us about the 1,600 branches under Labor. Tell us about that!

—This is just one bank—one area in Sydney. A further 68 branches were lost due to the St George and Advance Bank mergers. But banks appear to have seen the light and now seem to have backed away from further closures. They have underestimated the public feeling on this issue. Where have the Nationals been on this issue? The Queensland Nationals are so rattled they passed a resolution supporting the formation of a new Australian bank at their conference recently.
—That is because you closed down QIDC!

—Where have the Nationals been? Where have you been, and where are you going to vote today, Senator O'Chee? One Nation has put you out of a job because you have allowed this to happen over the last three years. You have run, you have hidden and you have paid the price. Banks must recognise that they have an obligation to their customers to provide accessible services. Pushing some customers who are the most vulnerable in our community into electronic banking, either by removing face-to-face access or making it so expensive that you cannot afford to use it, is unacceptable. Some may say a $2 over-the-counter fee is trifling. When you realise that two over-the-counter transactions will wipe out the GST compensation that this government plans to give pensioners after it introduces the GST you begin to realise the unfairness of this behaviour.

speech.para: Then there is the attitude that Mr David Murray, the head of CBA, demonstrated so clearly at an American Chamber of Commerce lunch in Sydney a few weeks ago when he made his now famous quote:

Instead of politically inspired letters that I get for closing a couple of branches, the people of Australia should be sending telegrams of congratulations to each of the major banks, and some of the others as well.

This is from the bank which has closed 223 branches—just a few, he said—in the last three years and which voted just recently to give Mr Murray $15 million worth of options as part of his remuneration. As we all know, Mr Murray was forced onto national TV and had to apologise.

I would like to return to the question of margins and interest rates. This is a critical area if a judgment is to be made about the banks and this government. This is the key decision. Much has been made about lower interest rates by the `big four' and the government, including the Treasurer, the Prime Minister, Senator Tierney and Senator O'Chee. They say the customers are the beneficiaries of lower interest rates.

In the early 1990s there were many complaints about the great spread of rates—the level of real, as opposed to nominal, rates. The banks had made some disastrous loans to entrepreneurs in the 1980s—don't forget that. They lost the money. What did they do to fix it? They repaired their losses over time by maintaining some of the highest spreads of rates in the world for many years. Remember that? Do you remember the big differences—the comparisons made with banks around the world? We were the worst.

You could argue that ordinary Australians were picking up the tab for the banks' poor lending practices to shonky entrepreneurs. This was the beginning of the anti-bank sentiment. You can pick it up from back then. It could be argued, if you wanted to be sympathetic to banks, that they made some massive losses and they had no choice—the parlous state of the balance sheets required some action.

Today we have a very different world. Despite claims by the `big four', I say to them and to the government that you cannot hide behind this low interest rate argument. The London Economist has exposed the real story. The spread—that is, the difference between the lending and borrowing rates in Australia as measured by the prime overdraft rate and the 90-day bank bill rate—is still the highest in the world for the 15 OECD countries that they surveyed. That is right—it is still the highest. This proves the lie. This is damning evidence. The falling margins allowing cross-subsidies is the argument for increasing fees, but the spread is still the greatest.

The banks point to the low interest rates and say, `Look, we're not making the money we used to,' but they are still trying to deceive ordinary Australians. It is not the five per cent or the six per cent rate that matters; it is the spread between what they are paying on the money that they are lending out and the money that they are receiving. It is the spread that matters. The government is facilitating this argument by allowing the banks to gouge huge fees while claiming they cannot afford to cross-subsidise. It is not the level of the interest rate that matters; it is the spread.

This is the sort of deceit that causes the ALP to demand formal monitoring of bank fees and charges and to seek to have the ACCC conduct this monitoring and, if necessary, full price surveillance. Policies that seek to force the poor, the old and the disadvantaged out of banks is un-Australian. It is the behaviour that evokes sympathy for calls for banking licences to be made conditional on the provision of appropriate transaction accounts for all Australians.

There has been much speculation in the markets following Don Argus's comments about the bank mergers. As Professor Tom Valentine and John Phillips, the former Deputy Governor of the Reserve Bank, agreed recently, the prime motivation for many takeovers was the megalomania of chief executives—bigger bank, greater status, bigger pay. That is from very senior individuals who have worked in the banking sector. That is not from some socialist left or Far Left Trotskyite; it is from Professor Valentine and a former Deputy Governor of the Reserve Bank.

Mergers are being driven purely and simply by the megalomania of chief executives and their egos. The NABs `national champion' line is a joke. Merge all four and you may get an internationally competitive bank, but allow two to merge and you will have no choice but to allow the other two to merge. Then what happens? Neither would actually make the top 20 of world banks and neither would fit the category of the national champion. So what is left? If this is the rationale, you are still short of your target. Do you allow the remaining two to merge? (Time expired).

talk.start.para: —The ALP has an absolute, colossal hide—moving a motion like this. What it completely overlooks is the ALP's appalling record on monitoring the evolution of the banking system. Senator Conroy, your ALP government was asleep for 13 years on this issue. What you have also completely overlooked in your contribution today is the transformation in banking created by modern telecommunications technology.

speech.para: We are in the midst of a banking revolution. The way we bank has changed incredibly rapidly, thanks to the technological advancements of the last few years. Today we can bank over the phone; today we can bank on the Internet. These changes are proceeding at an incredibly rapid pace and are going to make life easier for all of us. But, as we change, there is a transition period to be worked through. In the last few days we have heard about banks raising certain fees, and we understand why this has upset many people in Australia. Even the banks understand that they have upset their customers.

Westpac's short form annual report for 1998, which I received today, says, `Because of the way banks are changing and charging for their services, perceptions of banks have not always been positive.' People's perceptions about banks are not always positive. We all hate standing in lines; we all hate paying bank charges. But we all tend to love the 24-hour access to our money that ATMs provide on virtually every street corner. We all love being able to buy our groceries with electronic transfer through the EFTPOS transaction points. We love being able to withdraw money at service stations and to conduct our banking over the phone 24 hours a day. We love being able to shop around at the different banks for better deals, and that bank lenders and advisers will visit us now in our homes at our convenience. This is a massive change from banking practice 20 years ago. What we love most of all—and this is a point that Senator Conroy tried to hide—is the fact that interest rates are now down around five and six per cent—levels we have not seen in this country since the 1950s.

The banking industry is changing at an incredibly rapid pace and that is the change we are dealing with here today. According to the 1997 financial system inquiry report, people are also changing very much the way in which they bank and this has put pressure on the banks. The inquiry found that as more and more customers maintain transaction accounts with only working balances, net interest income declines forcing the institutions to rely more heavily on fee income. In the past banks covered these costs through higher interest rates on loans and lower interest rates on savings. Yet their real costs come from people's active transactions accounts and it is on these accounts that they have begun to levy charges. They are spreading their costs more fairly.

The Commonwealth Bank, whose announcement of fee increases sparked this debate, is the perfect example. The other side is complaining that the Commonwealth Bank is increasing fees on their costly services but they conveniently ignore the fact that they have announced a drop in fees on EFTPOS transactions in supermarkets, shops and service stations. Over the last few years we have had a vast network of cash points created by the EFTPOS system—electronic funds transfer at point of sale—right across the country in service stations, supermarkets and other places, creating an enormous increase in convenience, particularly as shops are now staying open for much longer hours.

This and phone banking are the way of the future. Now people can bank anywhere in Australia at the cost of a local call. They can pick up their phone and do their banking any time, day or night. When I rang the National Bank this morning I was told that this banking incurs no extra fees or charges. Already 30 per cent of Australians over 18 use phone banking. The banking industry is changing with this technology. Even as we speak, banking from your home or work through the Internet is becoming more and more common.

The biggest and the best change to banking in recent years though has been the huge drop in housing interest rates. We all remember what happened with interest rates under the Labor government. That is another point that Senator Conroy was not to keen to dwell on. Who remembers the 17 per cent interest rates and the crushing burden this placed on individual families and businesses? Who remembers that at that time the banks were struggling to survive? They were writing off billions of dollars in bad debts caused by the high interest rate policies that were forced on this country by inappropriate economic policies designed by Paul Keating, the Prime Minister at that time.

Since the coalition has come to power interest rates have fallen. They have fallen now from the high under Paul Keating of 17 per cent down to around 6.7 per cent. With competition banks are offering many home buyers rates even less than this. The Labor Party gets up here today and talks about this government monitoring bank fees. Under us housing interest rates are up to 10 per cent lower than what they were when you were in power. What did you do about monitoring bank fees in those 13 years you were in power? Four days before the 1996 federal election you said that you were going to write to the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission and request that the commission formally monitor fees and charges on bank retail transaction accounts. Before anything came out of that, you lost government. So your record in 13 years on monitoring bank fees was zilch. You did set up an inquiry about four years before you left government, but that just went around in circles. By the time you had finally lost government nothing had come of that process at all. You were the Rip Van Winkles of monitoring in relation to the banking industry. So again I repeat that you have a colossal hide getting up here today and moving a motion like this.

Let us look at another area under the coalition government. Senator Conroy talks about bank closures. He very conveniently talks about bank closures in the last three years. He does not compare that with bank closures over Labor's term in government. He also overlooks two other points: the number of bank agencies has increased in recent years and the access to facilities through Australia Post, such as giroPost, which gives people banking access where there are post offices, has also increased dramatically over that time. This is in stark contrast to what happened under Labor. Between 1991 and 1996, 1,600 bank branches and agencies closed their doors. This has affected some rural communities very harshly. In contrast to this the coalition is committed to ensuring that rural Australians have access to this very basic provision. For this reason this government has been proactive in this area—unlike the Rip Van Winkles opposite for 13 years.

With our policy at the last election we have created a program of rural transaction centres. Under this program there will be $70 million over the next five years to establish over 500 rural transaction centres. The great thing about the centres is that they are focused on smaller towns. If you go to the bigger centres in Australia such as Dubbo, Bathurst, Wagga and those sorts of places, you will find you have got a reasonable spread of banking facilities. Where there is a great lack of these facilities in Australia is in the towns of between 500 people and 3,000 people. They have always struggled to have adequate facilities.

We are now moving towards a better system for people in these communities. Banks have indeed closed some major branches, but the program of transaction centres will open banking facilities in these towns. It will provide not only banking facilities but a wide range of other facilities. There will be fax and phone services at these centres. There will be postal services, personal banking and limited business transactions, automatic tellers and Medicare Easyclaim. These facilities have not been in these towns before. So, instead of a retreat of services from the bush, this initiative of this government, the Rural Transaction Centre program, will actually advance more centres into the bush.

In addition, if we have a look at what has happened with the rural banking agencies, we find that that is also an improving trend. In 1995 there were 2,500 rural banking agencies; in 1998 there are 3,000. It has actually gone up by 500. On top of this there are the giroPost facilities that have been a recent phenomenon in Australia through Australia Post. There are now 2,720 of these. So, through what has happened with giroPost, through what has happened in expansion of agencies and through what we are going to do in rural transaction centres, there is an increase in banking services now and there will be more into the future. We are moving into the 21st century with the program that we have set in place to support banking facilities, particularly in the bush. And the banking industry is moving with us. What is important is that people are not left behind. The coalition's policies are making sure that this does not happen. We are making sure that the 21st century will start with low interest rates and banking that will be available to all Australians through the wonders of modern telecommunications technology.

talk.start.para: —I heard what Senator Tierney had to say on this matter and I do not believe that the government are moving towards a better system. I think the only thing he has got right this afternoon is the fact that people are upset about what the Commonwealth Bank has done—to charge its customers $2 to withdraw money from over the counter.

speech.para: The West Australian is just one of the papers that reported this. It drew people's attention to the fact that the charge for withdrawing over the counter goes from $1.50 to $2. In my terms, that is a 33⅓ per cent increase, and that is a massive increase when you consider the inflation we are currently faced with—low inflation which this government wants to brag about. And here we have a bank raising its charges by 33⅓ per cent purely and simply because the customer wants to deal with a real person on the other side of the counter. What the Commonwealth Bank is doing there is really a disincentive to employment and a disincentive for people to go and deal with their fellow human beings.

The West Australian article about the new charges says that the fee for ATM withdrawals with the same bank, the Commonwealth Bank, will go from 15c to 60c. That is a 300 per cent increase in the ATM charge from 1 December. One should note that that again is well in advance of the rate of inflation. On the other side of the ledger, though, they tell us that the EFTPOS charge will go from 45c down to 40c, a decrease of a mere 11 per cent. If you look at the strategy that is being used by the banks, you can clearly see that it is anti-employment, it is anti-job and it is anti-people. There is a clear disincentive to use the over-the-counter system where people are employed. What we see the banks doing is anti-employment, anti-people and anti-jobs.

It is interesting to look further at what the banks are really doing. In the Sydney Morning Herald of 12 November this year there is a big headline `$5.5 billion profit but big four on the nose'. There is no wonder why. The average person in the community sees this headline and they understand clearly why the banks are on the nose: $5.5 billion profit. The article in the Sydney Morning Herald points out that the banks' result of $5.5 billion was saved by the fact that the banks had a big jump in their non-traditional income areas such as fees and charges. That was the thing that saved their combined profit and kept it at the $5.5 billion mark. The article goes on to say that the only reason the result was not higher than last year's $5.6 billion was that the banks were spending `hundreds of millions of dollars on restructuring their organisations'. That is nothing more than a euphemism for cutting jobs and cutting branches, and that is precisely what the article goes on to point out.
The Sydney Morning Herald article says that during the past year the banks cut 6,000 jobs, despite several acquisitions. It says:
ANZ has led the way in cutting its workforce—by close to 5,000 people.

This, of course, is in an environment where we have unemployment as one of the worst cancers that our society can know. So what we have is a deliberate strategy on the part of the banks to be anti-employment, to get rid of and shed as many people as they can to take away the human face of banking.

It is interesting to look at a simple article with a simple headline in the Courier-Mail of 17 November. The headline says `$1m bonus for NAB razor man'. It is worth while reading this into the record. It says:
National Australia Bank's national managing director Don Argus scored a $1 million bonus last year as he culled more than 1200 jobs, shut 78 branches and increased bank fees.

What a tribute. `Disgrace' is the only word that can be used for that. That was his reward, and that is the reality of the real commercial world. Banks are not about customer service; they are not about giving a benefit to the customer.

It is interesting to look back in time at my own state. An article appeared in the Courier-Mail of Saturday, 1 June 1996. The article talked about bank branch closures in regional Queensland. It said:
The National Australia Bank will close branches in Surat, Jandowae, Kalbar, Bollon, Goombungee and Leyburn in the grain belt of the Darling Downs and Western Darling Downs.

This was the heart of National Party territory. Then—surprise, surprise—the then National Party minister responsible for rural communities, Di McCauley, was quoted as describing the NAB's move as `a kick in the teeth for the communities'. Mrs McCauley said that rural bank closures had become a worrying trend and she questioned the banks' decisions to put profit over service. That is the issue: profit over service. That is the only language that the banks know. McCauley, a National Party member and minister in the Queensland conservative government, went on to say:
Both the Government and the private sector have a responsibility to provide and maintain services to rural communities.
Rural communities have supported banks for many years during the good times and it is essential the banks reciprocate that support during the tough times.
Clearly, there was outrage within the ranks of the National Party when it was in government in Queensland at the move to close a number of banks on the Darling Downs.

It is also interesting that Wambo Shire Mayor, Robert Sparkes, a well-known member of the National Party in Queensland, said that his council had attempted to keep the bank in town by offering to transfer all its business to the branch. The article in the Courier-Mail said:
Sir Robert said the offer was rejected and the bank which has been in the town almost since the turn of the century would go.
He said the closure was part of a trend which would destroy Queensland's small towns.

Coming from Sir Robert Sparkes, that is very strong language indeed, and it shows the callousness of the banks' approach to rural and regional areas. The article continues with a quote from the Warroo Shire Council chief executive officer, Vaughan Becker, who said that the closure of the Surat branch would drain finance out of the community into neighbouring Roma. He said:
The council pays wages into a bank, Social Security does the same so when people go and get their cash in the nearest bank which is Roma, they will spend it there . . .

Those were prophetic words because, in a more recent article on page 12 of the Sunday Mail of 25 October this year, the headline said `Fanning the fury'. The article is on the closure of banks in rural and regional areas. It refers to the closure of the Westpac branch at Dimbulah, which is 90 kilometres west of Cairns. The article reports:
. . . shopowners' profits plummeted as residents, forced to make the 90km round trip to the nearest bank in Mareeba, took their daily business with them.
One of the major consequences of the desertion of the rural and regional areas by Australia's banks is that small business is suffering badly.

It was interesting to hear my colleague Senator Conroy refer to a statement by Mr Murray that people should send telegrams of congratulation rather than protest on bank closures. The article in the Sunday Mail refers specifically to the town of Mount Morgan where the Commonwealth Bank closed its branch. The article says:
On Friday, the Commonwealth closed its Mt Morgan branch.

Mr Murray's comments serve only to inflame the anger in rural Australia where the big four banks have close numerous branches in recent years sparking criticism they are bent on increasing profits at the expense of service and social obligations.
In fact, Reserve Bank figures reveal more than 506 bank branches closed in Australia in the 12 months to June 30.

That highlights what this issue is going to come to. It came to a head with the voting patterns in the recent federal election. Surprise, surprise—piggybacking on people's disenchantment with the federal government and its inability to protect the interests of people in rural communities, One Nation scored 18.83 per cent. Reality translates into electoral results.

In the same booth at Mount Morgan, the National Party could only score 20 per cent of the vote—and that is in a seat it holds. Across the state in rural and regional Queensland in the latest federal election, the National Party lost a senator to One Nation because of disenchantment with this government. The disenchantment is obvious in the following seats when you look at the percentage of votes for One Nation: Leichhardt, 13.89 per cent; Hinkler, 18.99 per cent; Maranoa, 22.4 per cent; Kennedy, 18.84 per cent; Capricornia, 13.9 per cent; and Wide Bay 26.33 per cent. The closure of bank branches is one of the major issues that fuels the disenchantment of the voters with the current government. Across the state, the Liberal Party got 30.86 per cent of the vote, down 8.43 per cent, and the National Party got 9.99 per cent, down 5.93 per cent, while One Nation scored 14.35 per cent.

Those figures highlight, in my view, the difficulties that this government has with issues like bank closures and the handling of bank charges. These matters sting the people who live in rural and regional areas and make them feel isolated and deserted. They feel no-one is concerned enough to take an interest in them at all.

Looking briefly at the closure of banks, I want to mention an analysis by the Centre for Australian Financial Institutions of just some of the problems faced by smaller regional and rural communities. It examines problems such as cheque handling and finds that there is no facility for small businesses to put their deposits in the bank on a daily basis, so their deposits are delayed. This is a cost in itself. It affects the cash flow of those businesses. If one looks at the issue of change—coinage—it finds that many small businesses find themselves stuck with high denomination notes and a lack of coinage. As a result, they have to take steps to have higher floats, which means greater security risks. Ultimately, that is an impost on small business and a burden that they have to carry.

The other issue I want to briefly address is credit, by retailers and the like, in the absence of banks. Their absence means that business is carrying a credit risk and also carrying a debt which is unserviced until the consumer pays—presumably at the end of the month, or whenever it might be. At the end of the day, wherever banks disappear in rural and regional areas—and there are no banks in many of these places now—it becomes an impost on the small business community.
Banks have abrogated their social and community responsibility. One must not be too amused at the fact that Westpac circulated to members in this Senate a copy—

talk.start.para: —Did you get one too? It is an amazing document.

—It is an amazing document, as Senator Schacht interjects. It is their most recent report. It is very glossy and very expensive—but what does this report spend its time addressing? It spends its time addressing issues such as these: `Why shouldn't there be a bank branch in every town', then `But aren't all banks the same', `Why are bank fees going up', `Who says banks have a social responsibility' and `Is making money good for the bank?' No-one is denying that organisations such as banks need to make a profit. But, as I said in the first instance, the four major banks made $5.5 billion—not to be sneezed at—and most of that is made on the backs of battlers and on the backs of the poor.

speech.para: What we have had circulated by Westpac today could only be described at best as an embarrassment to both Westpac and the government—because neither of them is prepared to address the issues. Neither of them is prepared to take on a social and community responsibility. Senator Tierney referred to rural transaction centres: these are very nice, but people want proper financial services in the rural and regional areas; they do not want to talk to machines. They do not want to press buttons over telephones for telephone banking. They do not want to be forced into those means of transaction; they want to talk with people. It is when they talk with people that they can get some good common sense—hopefully—so that, the end of the day, they can feel as if they are still a part of the human race.

This Westpac report does not serve as anything other than an embarrassment to that organisation and to the government. They are trying to explain away their antisocial behaviour while the government sits limply opposite and allows it to happen. The government has borne the consequences.
Government senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Well, you have lost a senator. Senator Patterson, you know that.
—And another one in New South Wales.
—That is right, in rural New South Wales as well.
—Two National Party senators hit the fence.

—Two from the National Party. The fact is that One Nation went out there and ran the campaign—and they ran it strongly—based on the fact that the government is seen to be inactive in this area. The government needs to show more concern for rural and regional Australia. It needs to show it, particularly, for pensioners, small business people, local councils and schoolchildren. School banking is being completely disrupted by the withdrawal of banks from these rural and regional communities. The government needs to jettison its wrongly held belief that the competitive market will provide cheaper, more effective services to the consumer—as the Assistant Treasurer said yesterday in response to a question. There is no doubt that the government is out of step and out of touch with reality. There is nothing to prove that the competitive market will provide cheaper and more effective services.

speech.para: Look at the situation in Dimbulah, in Surat, Jandowae, Goombundgeee and a number of other places—nothing is making their lives any better. There is no more effective service for those people and there is certainly nothing to guarantee that it is cheaper. All we see are these people being cut off from mainstream society. They are told they can go to GiroPost. They are told they can go to transaction centres. But, at the end of the day, they will make their decision at the ballot box. The government must take cognisance of this, for if they do not, then they will suffer the ongoing fate that awaits anyone who ignores the people. They started out by saying that they were going to be a government to govern for everyone. I think they have failed miserably on that account. Of course, this is only one major area where that is the case.

talk.start.para: —I have heard some interesting speeches in my time in here—
—That wasn't one of them.

—Thank you, Senator. The crocodile tears that the Labor Party are now crying are absolutely typical of the hypocrisy of people on the other side. Instead of heeding Mark Latham's advice and developing real policies for the future, Labor has come in here once again with a cynical, populist smear to attempt to gain points with the electorate. I do not think they have learnt anything from the last election. The Australian public saw through Labor—a policy free zone. Sorry, I should not say that; that is misrepresenting the situation. What policies they had they have just about jettisoned since the election.

speech.para: The community did not fall for the cynical ploys that passed for tax reform. All they could do with the ramshackle wholesale sales tax was to put a tax on caviar and take it off orange juice. This was a sales tax system under which frozen yoghurt was tax free but frozen yoghurt that tasted like ice-cream was taxable. One of the other classic ones was where you had strawberry Quik attracting a wholesale sales tax but chocolate Quik not attracting a wholesale sales tax. That is the sort of policy that Labor went to the last election with. All they were going to do to reform the mess in the taxation system was to put tax on caviar and take it off orange juice.

The other thing they were going to do was to extend the capital gains tax to items that people had previously purchased. I think that was Jenny Macklin's idea. Two days after the election, Mr Beazley jettisoned that bit of their policy. So the policy that they did have is in tatters. The opposition will win nothing from the cynical motion put forward today by Senator Conroy. You cannot keep treating the Australian people with contempt. If you do, you will be warming those opposition benches for a very long time.

Mr Hockey put it very well in the other place on 24 November when he gave us a bit of a history lesson on this issue of banks and bank closures. Between 1991 and 1996, over 1,600 bank branches and agencies were closed. Where were you all then? What were honourable senators on the other side doing about bank closures then?

You would think that Australia had begun on the day after the election in March 1996. You would think that nothing had happened beforehand and that Labor had not done anything to create the problems that existed. There is evidence that 1,600 bank branches were closing, with nobody expressing concern—except the member for Dickson, Ms Kernot, before she deserted the Democrats. When she was Senator Kernot, she asked a question in the Senate of Senator Cook, and Mr Hockey referred to this on 24 November. He said:

In the Senate on 31 May 1995, Senator Peter Cook was asked the following question without notice: `. . . what measures will the government take to ensure that banks fulfil their community service obligations by reforming practices your government—' that is, the Labor government—`has been carping about for five years, inquiring into for five years and also doing nothing about for five years?'
That was a now Labor member accusing the then Labor government of knowing nothing about banking for five years. Mr Hockey went on:

On 11 July 1995, the then Treasurer, Mr Ralph Willis, put out a press release with the following statement: `The Government agrees . . . on the need to supply better information to consumers so they can make the right choices about banking products that suit them. To spur this process, I will direct the new Australian Competition and Consumer Commission to formally monitor and regularly report on the financial services industry in relation to retail transaction accounts for a period of three years.' That was 11 July 1995. Nothing happened in the rest of July. Nothing happened in August. Nothing happened in September, October, November, December, January and February until we got to 26 February—four days before the federal election. Four days before the federal election, Ralph Willis put out another press release: `Labor to monitor fees and charges on retail transaction accounts'.
I found this speech quite interesting reading. I had forgotten this had happened. Mr Hockey continued:

It states: `A Labor Government will write to the Chairperson—' they are going to write to the chairperson—`of the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission . . . requesting the Commission to formally monitor fees and charges on bank retail transaction accounts.'

Mr Hockey was saying that, after 13 years, the Labor Party were going to do something about monitoring bank fees. They had 13 years to do something about it, but they did nothing. They come in here and have the gall to be critical of the coalition, yet they did nothing about it when they identified it as an issue.

We recognised that there had been a problem associated with the closures of banks. Instead of just saying we were going to write to a committee, we actually are doing something about it, as my colleague Senator Tierney said. We are introducing rural transaction centres—

talk.start.para: —Paid for by selling Telstra. So you are sacking more Telstra workers to pay for it.

—in recognition that rural communities have been affected by a decline in service provisions, particularly in those population centres where there are 5,000 people. This government is committed to ensuring that rural Australians have access to basic service provisions.
—Will you do it if you can't sell Telstra?

—In order to meet this commitment, the government has developed the rural transactions centre program. Senator Schacht is shouting from the other side of the chamber, `What are you going to do about it if you don't sell the next tranche of Telstra?' Senator, we can say to the people of Australia that we have a program and we have a policy to help people in rural Australia.

speech.para: The Labor Party cannot accept that we won the election and they are going to oppose everything we do. Out in the community people say to me, `How come the Democrats, Senator Harradine, the Independents and the Greens seem to have so much say in the Senate these days?' How come they have so much say? Because the Labor Party opposes every single thing—just about, although there was an exception yesterday on the migration bill. They oppose most of the major issues. They write themselves out of the equation and, by writing themselves out of the equation, they give the Democrats and the Independents all the say in the world.

On major issues we used to say, `The world's going to fall in. The sky's going to fall in. It's going to be terrible. But you won the election. Let the people judge you on your performance.' We did not give the minority parties the same authority. We were much more cooperative. But if you want to go on like that we will go out to the people and say, `If you don't get your transaction centres, that is because Labor has failed to accept that we won the election and will not let us implement our policies.' The answer to the question that Senator Schacht asked is: `If you don't get your transaction centres, blame the Labor Party.' There is the answer, Senator Schacht. I will keep telling the people in rural Australia that, and so will all my colleagues.

I also say to you that, when we were doing consultations around Australia for the International Year of Older Persons, older people indicated to us that banking was a concern. We heard that from a number of people. When Warwick Smith was minister he announced in the 1998-99 federal budget that there would be $13.4 million over four years for business and community partnership initiatives. The first initiative that was announced for that partnership money was a banking partnership between banks and community groups to help older Australians keep abreast of rapidly changing electronic banking and shopping.

As Senator Cooney said while he was speaking, we may as well go back to pedal radios. Senator Hogg wants to take us back to the age of the dinosaurs—back to the Dark Ages. Older people are capable of learning new skills. They have demonstrated that to us. They did not say to us, `We don't want it.' They said, `We want safer ATMs, we want to know how to use them and we want assistance.' They were not being dinosaurs like Senator Hogg. They are saying, `We can adapt and we can learn if we are taught how to do it.' So the banking partnership has been set up. I commend the Australian Bankers Association for their commitment and involvement in this project to assist older Australians learn how to use electronic banking and ATMs. They will address issues such as the size of the pad, the size of the screen and whether or not there is light on it, and all the other things that might make it more difficult for an older person to use electronic banking.

For Senator Hogg to assume that everyone has to go back to the Dark Ages is a very negative approach. I think it is a much more positive approach to say: `Yes, we'll work with you.' Older people have indicated that that is what they are prepared to do. This project brings together the Bankers Association and a number of important interest groups to represent the interests of older people. They will work in conjunction with the government, the banks and older people to address some of those concerns.

Instead of sitting and carping as Labor did for 13 years, we have taken a positive approach. We have developed the concept of transaction centres. We have been working in partnership with the Australian Bankers Association to address problems—they have acknowledged there are problems. This is a much more positive, constructive approach than the negative, carping approach of the opposition. The reason we are sitting on this side and Labor is sitting on the other side is that the Australian people recognise that what they want is people who have answers and are going to do things rather than talk about it and set up yet another committee or write to another chairperson.

I want to remind honourable senators that with the introduction of a GST—again, Labor sits over there and says, `Oh, we don't want to accept that you won the election and we're not going to let you implement your policies'—under the government's tax reform proposals financial services are input taxed. This means that there is no tax on outputs but the supplier cannot claim input tax credits. The financial service and the fee for the financial service are not subject to GST.

The abolition of wholesale sales tax and other taxes and reductions in excise mean that input costs to banks are expected to fall by approximately $670 million. When a financial institution provides a service such as investment advice or insurance for which there is a readily identifiable separate fee that will be subject to GST. Bank customers will be winners from tax reform. They will no longer have to pay $2.4 billion worth of taxes on bank accounts. When you add up your taxation at the end of the year, when you add up all the FIDs and BADs you pay, you will realise how much difference that will make to the expense of running a bank account. Labor's policy is for customers to keep paying $2.4 billion worth of taxes on bank accounts—ours is not.

The opposition comes in here and cries crocodile tears about banks closing when 1,600 bank branches closed in the last half of the Labor government. They did nothing. They talked about it and they talked about it until four days before the election when they issued a press release saying they were going to do something about it. No wonder the public are cynical about them. They sit here saying, `Oh, it's terrible.' They beat their breasts about there being charges and problems with the banks when they are pushing and supporting a policy that will mean that customers have to keep paying $2.4 billion worth of tax on bank accounts. I think that demonstrates the hypocrisy of the Labor Party. The fact is that they are a policy free zone. Labor needs policies. It is rare that I agree wholeheartedly with Lindsay Tanner, but he said, and I agree with him:
History shows that the Labor Party needs to do two things to win government. One is to reform itself and the other is to build the new agenda.

We have seen nothing on the part of the Labor Party to suggest anything about policies. All I can suggest is that the Labor Party develops a more constructive approach, a more constructive attitude and some real policies.

talk.start.para: —I was glad to hear Senator Patterson draw the attention of the chamber to the policy record of the Australian Democrats on the issue of banking services and, in particular, our concern about banking fees.
—You are acknowledging the late Senator Kernot.
—I acknowledge that one of our members may have left, but the policy remains the same.

speech.para: The issue of access to banking services is one which has received a great deal of attention, specifically over the past few years, definitely in the last few days, and rightly so. Over the past five years, bank fees and charges have increased, thousands of jobs have been cut within the sector, branches have been closed and bank profits have absolutely soared.

The Australian Democrats have long subjected banks and the financial services sector to close scrutiny and have applied equally close scrutiny to relevant government policies. Unfortunately, the history of policy development in this area is littered with initiatives which have favoured banks and shareholders over customers, and the developments of the last week in particular can be attributed in many ways to the current government's enthusiasm for competition as a panacea for service deficiencies.

In September 1997, the Treasurer, Mr Peter Costello, announced financial deregulation reforms which would, as he put it, `deliver billions of dollars of benefits for Australian business and consumers.' Of course, such statements in the context of financial sector reform are not new and, in making such expansive claims, the Treasurer echoed the sentiments of at least one of his predecessors, Mr Paul Keating, from the deregulation heydays of the 1980s.

The reforms of September 1997 sought to bring about greater competition within the banking sector by allowing building societies, credit unions, insurance companies, finance companies and superannuation funds to compete with banks. However, as the Australian Democrats said at the time, there are grave concerns in relation to the ability of smaller organisations to compete against the enormous market share of the big four banks.

I reiterate some of those concerns today. A survey published in the March 1998 issue of Choice magazine found a number of highly disturbing trends in bank operations. Included in the survey were comments from a range of customers clearly disappointed with what they perceived as declining levels of services and access. For example, one person stated:
I was happy with the personalised service that I received at my branch. Then they cut staff and I became just another number. Things that were done in hours now take days.
Another stated:
People shouldn't be penalised for using over-the-counter services, Not all of us are comfortable with new technology.
Another said:
It's time the banks were regulated again. It seems it's only since they were deregulated that they have become such bully boys.
And another said:
It's frustrating to hear about the major banks making huge profits, and then to be charged a fee for transactions.
Since deregulation, rather than making banking cheaper and generally better for all, I see a system where the rich do well and those with middle to lower incomes finance this in costs and fees.

When people were asked why they banked where they did, the results demonstrated why competition is an insufficient regulator of the banking industry. Forty-two per cent of those surveyed said they banked with a particular institution because they had always banked there. And 27 per cent of people banked with the institution where they had their home loan.

These figures clearly show that an overwhelming majority of people do not choose their financial institution on the basis of satisfaction, but often because it is easier to remain where they are. Less than one-quarter of those surveyed had changed institutions for their main transaction account in the past five years, despite recording declining satisfaction.

While consumers may be suffering from reduced access through branch closures, staff reductions and increased cost of services, the banks are certainly prospering. Over the past five years, bank profits have ballooned. In 1993, Westpac announced a profit of $39 million—a growth pattern replicated by the three other large banking institutions. This increased steadily to a profit of $1.29 billion in 1997. The big four banks reported profits over that five-year period of nearly $22 billion. These staggering profits were not achieved through traditional banking services such as home loans—which have become less profitable through competition and reduced interest rates—but through increased fees and charges and staffing cuts.

The consequences have clearly been the prioritisation of shareholders over services and employment. The Democrats find this outcome unacceptable and indicative of a need for greater regulation of the sector, as competition is simply not bringing about the results promised by government last year. But we are not the only ones: 80 per cent of respondents to the Choice magazine survey believe that the government should play a more active role in monitoring bank charges.

I note that the Australian banking sector compares poorly with overseas sectors. In Britain, most banks do not charge fees unless the account is overdrawn. Yet this government continues to allow banks—and I acknowledge the comments of Senator Patterson that it is not just this government but the former government as well—to continue practices which reduce access and increase unemployment.

While the government may claim that low interest rates are evidence of its performance in this respect, the fact is that low interest rates have had the effect of reducing the profitability of the lending side of banking activities. But rather than absorb this lessened profitability, the banks are looking to customers to make up their profits—and that is usually through increased fees and charges.

It is exactly this kind of activity which the Democrats argue requires greater regulation, and Australian consumers are clearly looking to the government to do this. Every time people go to the bank, to the supermarket, to pay an instalment on their home loan, or to an ATM, the often excessive fees remind them of the failure of the government's `red-hot' competition policy to protect them from bank profiteering. Of course, not only has the failure to adequately regulate banking activity resulted in increased costs to consumers; it has also resulted in massive job shedding in the sector. I note that since 1990 more than over 58,000 jobs have been lost.
The Democrats support the general business motion before the chamber today, moved by Senator Conroy. We support part (a) which refers to:

the Federal Government's callous disregard and total lack of interest in ensuring that the community has access to both affordable and accessible banking services, as evidenced by the fact that under the Howard government over 484 bank branches were closed in 1997-98

We support condemnation of job losses. I am keen to give a member of the government time to respond. I see Senator Payne looking keen to attack this issue. We do not have much time, however. Part (b), the failure of the government to formally monitor bank fees, is something we condemn. We have grave concerns with that aspect. But with regard to the second part of part (b), `rule out a goods and services tax being applied to bank service charges', I put this question to members on the opposite side: has the government clearly ruled out a goods and services tax being applied to bank service charges?

talk.start.para: —You are going to take it out to 6 p.m., and then it will be stumps.

—Senator Schacht, I am quite happy to allow time for a member of the government to answer my question which is: has the government ruled out a goods and services tax being applied to bank service charges?
—No, they haven't.

—I want to hear that from the government because there has been some suggestion that they are prepared to rule that out. I am prepared to give the government the benefit of the doubt because I would like to have that part of the motion clarified. Senator Patterson was quite right in suggesting that the Democrats have a history of drawing attention to the matter of bank fees and services.
—I did not say that. You have misrepresented totally what I said.

—I thought I was complimenting Senator Patterson on her speech. In that case, independent of Senator Patterson's comments, the Democrats have often scrutinised government policy on this matter and have certainly drawn attention to the issue of job losses in the sector. Indeed, I asked the Assistant Treasurer two questions this week about the issue of bank fees and competition. I was keen to find out what criteria were considered appropriate for the banking sector to meet before competition was believed to be considered appropriate so that mergers could take place. The Prime Minister has said that no more mergers should necessarily be agreed to unless a level of competition that is adequate has been reached. But we are still not quite sure of the detailed criteria to which the Prime Minister was referring when he made his statement the night before last. So I am still very keen to have that detailed criteria clarified by the government—what constitutes appropriate or adequate competition—before mergers are allowed to proceed.

speech.para: I really believe we have a do-nothing Treasurer on this issue. We have heard the other Assistant Treasurer, Mr Joe Hockey—again I note that the web site still has not specified what his duties are—give a spirited defence of the banking sector. I thought it would be very interesting to see whether or not his views and those of Senator Rod Kemp—the Treasurer's right-hand man, as I like to think of him—were the same. But we were unable to get an exact answer to that question from Senator Kemp. He was not sure what competition was appropriate. We were not sure whether he agreed with Mr Joseph Hockey and his comments in the House.

Certainly I disagree that those people who dare to speak up and challenge the notion that increased banking fees, reduced services, staffing cuts and other job losses are necessarily subsidising an old banking system. In fact those people are just ensuring that customers have their rights respected and have access to banking services in all areas—not just in urban areas but also in remote and regional areas—and that people do not have to face prohibitive fees and charges in order to use those basic banking services.

talk.start.para: —Senator Schacht, in calling you I remind you that there are fewer than four minutes left in this debate.
—He is getting succinct.
—And to the point.

—Absolutely, and to the point. I am always to the point when I am attacking the Liberal Party. In rising to support this motion by Senator Conroy, I agree with Senator Stott Despoja that this government should answer the simple question: will the GST apply to loan application fees, loan establishment fees, mortgage insurance fees and real estate valuation fees? It was an answer that the Treasurer could not give yesterday in the House of Representatives, so that is going to be a major issue; they obviously cannot work it out. If the GST does apply, it will be an additional impost on all Australians in the banking system and will, I suspect, further encourage the banks to close their retail outlets around Australia.

speech.para: In Australia at the moment we have the banks arguing that they should be allowed to merge. We have the NAB making it quite clear that they want to take over the ANZ bank. I saw only two days ago that they have called on the services of Mr Michael Kroger, a former President of the Liberal Party in Victoria, to be an adviser. He is to be paid a success fee, apparently, if the merger goes through. What is Mr Kroger's skill in being employed by the NAB? He has only one: he apparently is a close friend of Mr Costello, the Treasurer.

talk.start.para: —Has he got any friends?

—That is the one we do know he has, Senator Quirke. We do know that Mr Kroger was instrumental in getting Mr Costello his preselection when the Liberal Party dumped Roger Shipton as the member for Higgins in 1990 at a time when Mr Kroger was getting rid of all the small `l' Liberals in the Victorian Liberal Party. We know that only 18 months ago Mr Kroger was on a success fee from Mr Packer to get the cross-media ownership rules changed. I said in the Senate at that time that I had been given information that the success fee was $7 million. So you can imagine what the success fee would be if he was able to get Mr Costello to change his mind and allow these two very large banks to merge. It would run into tens of millions of dollars, not $7 million.
