speech.para: Of course Mr Kroger, who runs this merchant bank called J T Campbell, as I understand is the name of it, which does not seem to be a genuine merchant bank. It is about making political deals—providing services to the Liberal Party and its allies to achieve political deals. This is the way you do business in the Liberal Party and Mr Kroger has hung his shingle out accordingly. That is why there is great cynicism among the Australian public about the role of banks and the Liberal Party in Australia. The ordinary people of Australia know that when the banks are allowed to merge, if Mr Costello agrees to Mr Kroger's blandishments, it will be the ordinary Australians who lose services through the further closure of regional banks and retail banking services around Australia.
Debate interrupted.

talk.start.para: —Order! It being 6 p.m., the Senate will proceed to consideration of government documents.

—There are 114 government documents and an audit report listed for consideration on today's Notice Paper and there is a limit of one hour for their consideration. To expedite the consideration of the documents, I propose, with the concurrence of honourable senators, to call the documents in groups of 10. Documents called in each group to which no senator rises will be taken to be discharged from the Notice Paper . Documents not called on today will remain on the Notice Paper .

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 12 November, on motion by Senator Bartlett:
That the Senate take note of the documents.

talk.start.para: —I would like to talk to documents 1 and 2, the report Parental child abduction, January 1998 and the report Child contact orders: Enforcement and penalties, June 1998 . These documents deal with one of those areas of law that encompass some of the most tragic incidents that occur in the community; that is, in the area of family relationships as between spouses, as between parents and children. It is an area where there have been very tragic incidents taking place over the years and where such incidents will take place in years to come because it is an area that you can never get right. You have a breakup of an intimate relationship and you have children subject to awful pressure. These problems are society's problems and society has set up the Family Court to accommodate them.

speech.para: I notice in today's Australian that Evan Whitton, who writes much about the law and raises great issues that ought be discussed more than they are—I think the issues of how the law confronts people in society and how society accommodates its relationships through the courts are matters of great moment and should be discussed more often than they are, particular in this place—says there is a need to change the law, and there is a need for that to happen. The Family Court is one area where change could occur, and the Chief Justice of that court and his fellow judges are very intent on that happening.

One way the court can change would be to have available to it means other than simply adjudication to settle problems that come before it. For example, mediation is an instrument that the court looks to as a means of resolving these great personal issues which come before the court. It is a pity therefore that the court does not get the support it should from government. There should be two things done. First of all, there should be encouragement for the court to take mediation within its jurisdiction, in preference to mediation being done outside the court. There is no doubt that there are some great people doing great work outside the court in the area of mediation but, fundamentally, the best work is going to be done within the court because that is where the authority is. People come and see the court as a place where there is authority to decide the disputes that lay between the them. Governments should finance and give resources to the courts in greater amounts than presently is the case.

Secondly, the government, particularly the Attorney, should encourage the court to undertake this process of mediation, it being one of a number of means that might otherwise be available. Counsel settles most of the cases; the court adjudicates on others. Mediation ought to be another way of doing it. If the court were able to pursue the course that it wants, a lot of the problems that we have with families breaking up—and I notice document 1 talks a lot about parental child abduction—would be solved.

talk.start.para: —There is a fair degree of wisdom in some of the things that Senator Cooney has just said. He is in fact a very distinguished chairman of the Senate Legal and Constitutional Affairs Committee and is also a very experienced member of the bar. But I think sometimes we overlook part of the problem and that is we try to fix people's matrimonial difficulties after they become almost irretrievable. I think much more effort needs to be put into ensuring that people go into marriage understanding that it is a commitment. They also have to be supported through the marriage before they get to a situation where you have to call in a mediator in the court. Everybody is going to have arguments in their marriages, some more than others. We need to have a system in place that prevents the breakdown because, once the relationship has broken down, it is very difficult to retrieve the situation.

speech.para: I think all honourable senators would know, from their own experience, the experience of having constituents come to them, that once you get to the point where people are in court, the attitude is not one of compromise, it is one of vindictiveness and bitterness and frequently, tragically, it is one in which the children of the marriage are used as negotiating pawns or victory tokens in the vindictive battle between husband and wife. Not always do the parents understand that they are using the children as negotiating pawns or victory tokens but, in fact, subconsciously that is what is happening.

Yes, we have to work very hard on repairing family breakdowns, because the cost of family breakdowns is great, but we also have to work very hard at ensuring that we prevent those family difficulties becoming irretrievable breakdowns because that substantially reduces the cost. Let me explain what I mean by that. First of all, if we prevent a marriage becoming irretrievably broken, we reduce all of the court costs to which these reports and Senator Cooney in his learned contribution have referred. If people patch up their marital difficulties before they get to court, none of these expenses are incurred. That is a big saving of their money and the government's money.

Secondly, there is a huge social cost from not sorting out marital problems. Senator Cooney might correct me if I am wrong, but evidence was presented to the Senate Legal and Constitutional Affairs Committee several years ago that in 60 per cent of cases of divorce with children, the parent who has care of the children moves more than 600 kilometres from the matrimonial home within the first six months. Living in Cairns, I frequently see cases where people have moved to Cairns to get away from their partner because Cairns is as far as you can reasonably go along the bitumen. I know many people who will go from Perth to Cairns, because Cairns is the furthest city from Perth, to get away from their former spouse and to take the children with them.

What is the social cost if that continues to occur? First of all, there is a social cost because people's lives are scarred. I am not talking about the parents; I am talking about the children. These people's lives are scarred. To make it worse, it is a statistical fact that a child is more likely to be abused by a step-parent than by their own parent. It is a tragic thing and that is no aspersion on many good step-parents, but it is a statistical fact. Secondly, the incidence of crime amongst children from broken families is tragically higher. If this country is to eliminate those costs and those difficulties, we have to work at repairing marital difficulties before they become breakdowns, because in that way the long-term benefit to Australia is quite enormous.

talk.start.para: —I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

speech.para: Leave granted; debate adjourned.

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 12 November, on motion by Senator Sandy Macdonald:
That the Senate take note of the document.

talk.start.para: —I believe this annual report will be the last report of Wool International, although obviously there will be one dealing with the remainder of this year. Rather than looking at the unfortunate circumstances that have occurred in recent times and the disrepute that Wool International has fallen into, I want to take a broader look at what has occurred since 1990, when the wool industry was confronted with a 4.8 million bale stockpile and a $2.8 billion debt. We must recognise that it has been no mean achievement since then to reduce that stockpile to 1.1 million bales and to reduce the debt to about $230 million, which is where it stands today.

speech.para: We must also recognise the incredible contribution that has been made by the growers in the industry itself in picking up the mistakes that were made during the previous 10 years, particularly the late 1980s when the reserve price ran amuck. In fact, it went very close to destroying what is generally recognised as the founding industry and one of the most important industries in this country. It is still one of the most important industries in this country. It contributes close to $4 billion of export income a year, despite the difficulties. It is an industry which I am confident will grow back.

I want to get a theme through the events of this period, if only it can be seen as a lesson. We started off with the debt reduction scheme. That worked relatively well for about 18 months. It then fell foul because of certain circumstances. The industry took 18 months while it argued about what to do next, taking millions of dollars out of growers' pockets. We then had the Garnaut report. We switched from the debt reduction scheme to the fixed schedule. Once again, from 1993 onwards that worked reasonably well for about 18 months before falling into disrepair because it was no longer suitable.

The industry then argued for another 18 months until we came into government. In 1996 we went to the flexible schedule. Once again, that worked well until December 1997 when things changed. We had the Asian meltdown. Again, the industry got itself into a terrible bind, arguing about what to do next rather than putting its own prejudices aside and dealing with the particular issue, and that was the loss, once again, of an enormous amount of dollars and cents out of growers' pockets. I make the point that, up until this government implemented its first freeze, there had been a bipartisan approach in this parliament to dealing with the issues and the industry.

When it became obvious we had to have a freeze, for whatever inexplicable reason, the Labor Party took a different course and opposed that. In that process I believe they have delayed unnecessarily the process of adjustment that was required at this time. From December 1997 through to August we saw wool go into free fall. We saw it drop some 160c. We saw $200 million wiped off the value of the stockpile. We saw over $100 million wiped off the value of the growers' stockpile. None of this would have happened if we had had strong leadership in the wool industry and people who had the leadership ability to show some flexibility and deal with the problem when it arose. It should have been very obvious to people involved in the industry that with the Asian meltdown if you take one hundred million kilos out of the marketplace there is going to be price damage and unnecessary oversupply of wool. Virtual mayhem was created in people's homes in terms of the reductions in their income.

The basic message I want to give is that the next part of the process—the freeze, the legislation we have coming up shortly in this place, privatising the wool industry and putting it on a true commercial basis—must happen quickly. It must not be delayed in this place. People cannot treat wool growers as pawns any longer. I declare an interest in this, which I should have done at the start, as a wool grower. I am sick and tired of being played for a dummy by the leadership aspirants in our industry who have chosen to put their own personal gains in front of the gains and rights of individual growers. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I was not intending to speak on this matter, particularly as a debate on the bill the government has before the Senate is imminent and, indeed, there is a legislation committee inquiry on this matter commencing at 8 o'clock tomorrow morning. However, I could not allow the comments of Senator Crane on this matter, particularly with regard to the ALP not sharing the government's position on the legislation currently before the Senate. Indeed, our position is taken by a great many people in the industry.

speech.para: I do not seek to make a judgment that those people who are opposed to the freeze are wrong or are taking that decision based solely on particular personal advantage considerations. But I do say that we are quite well aware that the then minister responsible for this area, Mr Anderson, when the matter went to cabinet did not propose the course of action the government is now taking. He proposed other measures, not the freeze which is the subject of this legislation. As I said before, we saw the almost unprecedented event of a National Party minister, for what is a National Party constituency predominantly—and certainly a rural constituency in New South Wales and Victoria, and I would have thought in Queensland—go to the cabinet with a proposal not for a freeze but for other measures and have his position overturned, and a position proposed by Liberal Party members of the coalition for a freeze succeed.

That situation is almost unprecedented in relation to this type of legislation. But the question of what should happen to this legislation is in the hands of the Senate now and the Senate Rural and Regional Affairs and Transport Legislation Committee will conduct a hearing tomorrow and will hear the views of industry participants and representatives. I know from having looked at submissions which are before that inquiry that there is far from unanimity on the question of whether there should be a freeze or not.

I can say that the Tasmanian Farmers and Graziers, the organisation that represents I believe 80 per cent or more of wool growers in my state, have presented a submission in which they are very clearly opposed to this legislation. So for Senator Crane to attempt in some way to represent the Labor Party on this issue as being unrepresentative or as taking a position which is somehow detrimental to the industry because we do not agree with the government is a position I reject. Having said that, I understand from comments Senator Woodley has made that it is likely that the Democrats will support the government in this legislation. If that is the case—and everyone can count—the legislation will succeed, but I have to say that Senator Crane's suggestion that we have somehow delayed the process is wrong.

talk.start.para: —I didn't say that either. Read Hansard .

—I think you may, when you see the Hansard , Senator, find that that is the implication of what you said. We will find that the delay has been caused because the government acted without proper legal advice, because it purported to direct a freeze on Wool International when that was not an activity that could take place without a change in legislation and that, because of the timing of the decision and the fact that the parliament did not sit following the cabinet decision until the election, it was impossible for that to be implemented. (Time expired)

speech.para: Debate (on motion by Senator O'Chee) adjourned.

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 12 November, on motion by Senator Bartlett:
That the Senate take note of the document.

talk.start.para: —This report deals with the Social Security Appeals Tribunal for 1997-98. This is quite an outstanding body which reviews decisions made within certain departments. It deals in a generic sense with what its title indicates; that is, with people who rely on funds paid by the state to sustain life. It is for government and parliament to set policy and it is for administrators to make decisions about particular matters. But, when matters as fundamental as whether people have the wherewithal to sustain life are concerned, it is proper that there ought to be a review. This review system is a good one.

speech.para: Much is made in this chamber about the amount of money that has been saved by establishing that people who are receiving social security should not get it and, if people do not fit within the description provided by the law, that is right. But on many occasions people lose their income because of wrong decisions, and this body is set up to review those. Therefore it is a most important and essential body.

From page 39 to 47 of the report a number of names are listed. I want to pay tribute to those people because, although they certainly are paid, they do give of their time to do some outstanding work that brings justice to people who otherwise would not get it. I notice, for example, that under `Canberra' Helen Watchirs's name appears amongst those who are legal members of the tribunal. She is a woman of quite outstanding ability and of great disposition.

I note too that Deirdre FitzGerald has ceased to be the senior member in Melbourne. I notice that she was appointed from 22 February 1989 to 31 March 1997 and from 16 April 1997 to 31 December 1997. She is another woman of quite outstanding ability. I should perhaps indicate something of a remote interest in this. Many years ago, she was a partner of my wife. I think that, way back when they started, they were the only women partners of a firm situated in the city of Melbourne. It is good to see that she has gone to this tribunal and done great work on it.

I will return to the main theme that I want to take up in this speech. When we are reviewing decisions of government, it is important to remember what is appropriate for judicial review. Decisions made in respect of particular people should be very much subject to judicial review. Policy, of course, should not; it is for politicians to make policy. It would be a shame to see the judicial review system, as it has been set up over the years in this parliament and in state parliaments, disappear or be prejudiced to the point where people are not getting the sort of justice they are entitled to.

talk.start.para: —I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

speech.para: Leave granted; debate adjourned.

subdebateinfo.title: Australian Wool Research and Promotion Organisation

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 12 November, on motion by Senator Bartlett:
That the Senate take note of the document.

talk.start.para: —Once again, I declare an interest in this as a member of a family partnership growing wool. The report relates to the Australian Wool Research and Promotion Organisation, otherwise known as AWRP and the development, in recent times, of the Woolmark company, which had its origins in the International Wool Secretariat.

speech.para: This coming Monday—I will not dwell on it—we have what will be, I believe, a very important annual general meeting of wool growers in Goulburn to deal with the functions and operations of AWRP. Whatever comes out of that meeting—whether or not the no-confidence motion is carried and whether the accounts are received—I believe that we will see the beginning of very major changes in the way wool research, development, promotion and marketing is carried out in this country.

There is a mood, if I can put it that way, in the bush where growers, who have put some $8.5 billion over the last 20 years into research, promotion, marketing and development, are saying that they have had enough of funding that operation when they do not seem to be getting the results they should be getting out of it. I believe that we will see very quickly this organisation run to a totally commercial operation. I believe that we will see it move to becoming a corporate company where directors will be elected by the growers or shareholders who provide the money. They will have to contest elections on an annual or three-year basis, depending on the structure that comes out of it.

As a senator from Western Australia in particular—but I think I can also speak for those across Australia—the sooner that happens to the structure and all the funding becomes contestable and accountability is treated as though that operation were a normal corporation or company, the better. Bearing in mind that this year is a difficult year—wool prices have been down; there has been much less money available and AWRP has had to dig into reserves—AWRP will still have a budget well in excess of $100 million, which is much greater than the cotton industry, which is run on much more commercial lines.

The wool industry at this time, and the aspect of it that I have referred to, faces what I would call a commercial revolution. Growers will demand that each dollar and cent they put in be totally accountable. The spending of that money will become contestable. They will get private operators into the promotion field. They will spread their arms wider in terms of the dollars they spend on research and development. They will develop a focus that looks very carefully at the organisation if they are going to continue to have four per cent or thereabouts of their proceeds taken out of their cheques before they get them. They want to see results. They want to see dollars and cents back in their pockets. They want to see the industry start to grow again. They want to rebuild their farming structures. They want to deal with the infrastructure on their properties. They want to make sure that those people who have served the industry well for a long time are not forgotten. Those people who seem to have been forgotten—particularly by some people on the opposite side of the chamber—are the shearers, rouseabouts, wool classers and transport operators. I have listened to much of the debate on this. I have not once heard the spokespeople who represent the Labor opposition talk about the people who service the industry. They are the most valuable asset we have in the wool industry. They make it tick. Look at the figures for the multiplier effect on employment. There is no industry in Australia that generates employment like the wool industry. We must make sure that what occurs after Monday results in a much stronger, more focused market, research and promotion effort. (Time expired)
I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 12 November, on motion by Senator O'Chee:
That the Senate take note of the document.

talk.start.para: —This report is a very instructive one, as with many of the other documents here. It is probably worth pointing out, by way of introduction, the purpose and mission of the Australian War Memorial. Its purpose, as stated in the report, is to commemorate the sacrifice of those Australians who have died in war. Its mission is to assist Australians to remember, interpret and understand the Australian experience of war and its enduring impact on Australian society. Whatever philosophy and approach one takes to defence issues and to issues of armed conflict, I think that purpose and that mission are very laudable.

speech.para: The War Memorial performs a very important and significant service to the Australian community, and I believe it performs it very well. Some of the details in the report highlight the number of people that are involved on a daily basis with the activities of the Australian War Memorial. According to the report, the current staff totals 220-odd people and overall operating expenses in the last year were about $24.5 million. It is interesting in looking at some aspects of the report to see the huge range of activities that the War Memorial facilitates or sponsors. It is obviously well known in terms of the building itself and the various displays and information within it, but there has been quite a huge number of publications, papers and presentations at conferences, seminars and lectures that have been facilitated by the War Memorial for a wide range of people on an enormous number of topics.

There have also been a large number of gallery talks in the War Memorial throughout the course of the year from many people with actual experiences of war, giving details of the impact of war on people, on families and on whole societies and nations. Many scholarships and fellowships are provided by the War Memorial for various activities, whether it is purely historical documentation of people's experiences or whether it is technical stuff, such as one item here, to do with preventing the deterioration of rubber and rubber like products and materials and generally preserving items. As a memorial, it is also a place that is visited many times by people from overseas, dignitaries and official parties from overseas, and obviously it provides a quick, readily accessible but very comprehensive window to people from overseas about the Australian perspective on war.

I would like to mention briefly one issue in relation to the War Memorial which has had a little bit of coverage in the last week or two, which is whether or not the War Memorial should be involved in recognising and commemorating the wars or conflicts within Australia between the original inhabitants of this country and the invaders. I should say that there are other words that people might like to choose that are less confronting, but certainly people from Europe and other areas came in and clearly took that land away from the original inhabitants. On many occasions during that period that resulted in armed conflict and resistance, and obviously death, suffering and hardship as a result.

It is widely recognised that those conflicts have not had a lot of attention in our concept of our history, and it is an interesting and important issue as to how that might be built into the ongoing framework of the Australian War Memorial. I do not pass an opinion one way or the other on it other than to say that it is important that these conflicts are recognised and it would be worthwhile for the War Memorial to turn its attention to it. Coming back to its original purpose of commemorating the sacrifice of those Australians who have died in war and in armed conflict, it does seem to me that it is an important topic that the War Memorial and the people involved in it, who clearly take their responsibilities seriously, would do well to give some thought to.

talk.start.para: —I will declare an interest, which is that I, like a number of other members of this chamber and also the other place, have been a contributor to the War Memorial in the past, and I expect I shall be so in the future. I know that there are many honourable senators, like Senator Hogg, I suspect, who are in that capacity. He is not the only one on the other side; I know that there are many supporters of the War Memorial on both sides of the chamber.

speech.para: There are many things that the War Memorial staff do which go unnoticed. We notice the exhibits, we notice the tanks, we notice the planes and we notice the cenotaph. But what is often unnoticed is the immense care and attention given by staff of the Australian War Memorial to the needs and wishes of visiting veterans. Recently I had the great honour to accompany a group of veterans from an organisation with which I am associated, the Australian-Chinese Ex-services National Reunion, to the War Memorial to lay a wreath in respect of their former comrades. We were met by the Director of the War Memorial and a number of members of the staff. There was a wreath which was attended to by a member of the staff, who was the bearer of the wreath. There were members of staff assigned to be at the War Memorial to care for the veterans and their families, to attend to any requests that they had and to stand as an escort for those veterans until such time as they left the memorial.

I think this is a very fine thing that the Australian War Memorial does. It extends to our veterans the sort of respect which they deserve but which they would probably not ask for themselves. It is a fact that this respect is given without asking, which shows that the staff of the War Memorial treat their role as more than a job—in fact consider themselves, I would suspect, as the sacred guardians of the memories of the thousands of Australians whose lives have been lost in conflicts throughout the years. I do believe that we should remember the wars, we should remember and preserve the artefacts and the records, we should continue the research work, but we should not forget the role which is played by the staff of the Australian War Memorial in attending to our veterans when they visit, because it is a very important part of ensuring that we do not forget.

talk.start.para: —I concur with the comments of Senator Bartlett and Senator O'Chee on the Australian War Memorial. It is unfortunate that so many reports tabled in this place fly through without being given much care or attention. Since I have been here, I have tried to speak on this particular report on each occasion. The War Memorial is a significant place for Australians, and it is a significant place in this capital. There is no doubt that the work of the War Memorial is not given by many people the recognition it deserves. I hope this shrine does not lose its significance as time goes by.

speech.para: To pick up a point made by Senator O'Chee, flicking through the report I noted on page 30 a photograph of a group of voluntary guides celebrating Volunteers Week at the memorial. That picture alone says a lot about the dedication, time, effort and energy which is put in by a number of voluntary guides who take their work at the memorial very seriously and who are very well received by the public.

In the director's corporate overview on pages 4 and 5, Steve Gower gives a succinct but clear view of the work undertaken over the last 12 months, and of the work which will take place in the future. He refers to the fact that the largest and most complex activity during the year was undoubtedly the refurbishment of the memorial's galleries. One of the features of the War Memorial at this stage is that it is undergoing a great deal of refurbishment. This will benefit the younger generations well into the future.

The director also refers to the restoration of the main building and to the first stage of the development of the memorial sculpture garden, which was completed during the year. He draws attention to a couple of significant events. The first was the central feature of the Merchant Navy memorial—the Dennis Adams sculpture called `Survivors'. It is fitting that members of the Merchant Navy have now been acknowledged for their role in the various wars that we have been involved in.

Another initiative is the establishment of a servicewomen's memorial, which will be incorporated into the next stage of the garden's development. The role that women played in wartime is sometimes overlooked. The women who served this country so admirably will now get proper recognition. I also note that another group which has sometimes felt left out—the British Commonwealth occupation force in Japan—is also going to be recognised for its service to the nation. That group has also felt isolated on some occasions.

One of the most pleasing aspects of Steve Gower's report is that, as he says, it was a successful year for the travelling exhibition program which is run by the War Memorial. The map on page 37 of the report shows that the travelling exhibition went far and wide throughout Australia. This can only serve our nation well. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

subdebateinfo.title: Australian Industrial Relations Commission and Australian Industrial Registry

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 12 November 1998, on motion by Senator Hogg:
That the Senate take note of the reports.

talk.start.para: —Document No. 11 is the reports for 1997-98 of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission and the Australian Industrial Registry. I want to go through the significant part of the report which is on the termination of employment matters. Clearly, there is still a heavy workload for the Australian Industrial Relations Commission and the registry. That, of itself, is good. But on the issue of termination of employment, the report is quite specific. It tells us very clearly of the large number of people who felt disadvantaged by the termination of their employment and who have sought redress through the processes available through the commission.

speech.para: Interestingly, the bulk of the applications—61 per cent—were made in Victoria. In New South Wales, there were 1,291; the Northern Territory, 260; Queensland, 644; South Australia, 284; Tasmania, 112; Western Australia, 287; and the Australian Capital Territory, 253. It is interesting to note also that there were a number of appeals against decisions of the commission on the matter of jurisdiction—10 upheld; 23 dismissed. Whilst there were 33 cases in total, nearly one-third of those based on a jurisdictional argument were able to be brought forward before the tribunal.

On the matter of merit, six were upheld as opposed to 20 being dismissed. One appeal under `Other', which concerns costs, and one concerned with remedy, were both dismissed. It is interesting though that there is still a need for people to seek redress where they feel they have been wrongly done by in their dismissal. Table 5 gives us a fairly reasonable picture of why these cases were either settled or withdrawn—or whatever may well have happened to them.

Of the 7,341 cases totally finalised, 4,094 were settled by conciliation. That shows that in over 50 per cent of the cases conciliation, which should underpin the industrial relations system, worked. Whilst there may well have been a substantial disagreement which caused termination—the outcome is not evident there—at least they were able to resolve the problems.

A total of 1,257 cases were withdrawn, settled or otherwise discontinued. Only 231 were dismissed at a preliminary stage on the threshold jurisdiction grounds, including `out of time'. One could not, by any stretch of the imagination, imply from what one sees in this report that these matters taken by the complainants were in any way trivial. There were a number, of course, that were unable to be settled by conciliation, and they totalled 1,731.

There are further charts throughout the document which, again, give a better insight as to what happened to those cases. For example, there were 619 substantive arbitrations, which represented 27.8 per cent of the cases. When one considers the number of dismissals that took place, that is a relatively low frequency. It shows that the protection afforded by the act is undoubtedly accessed and is warranted in this day and age. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I would like to address the same report from the Australian Industrial Relations Commission, a body which, along with its predecessors, has been a central part of business life, industrial life and working life in Australia for almost all of the history since Federation, and it is important that this body be maintained. I say that not only because of the great history and the great tradition that the body has and the great work it presently does but because of some research that has come out of America. I mentioned this earlier in the day. It is research that I have been referred to by Max Ogden, an eminent member of the Australian Council of Trade Unions. He referred me to an article in the Scientific American , a very eminent and respected magazine from the United States which deals with research in the area of unions and enterprises. It is important because not enough research is done in this area. This research shows some very interesting things.

speech.para: The opening paragraph of the article, which was in the August 1998 edition of Scientific American, states:

After nearly a century of union management warfare in the U.S., a series of nationwide surveys showing that union shops dominate the ranks of the country's most productive workplaces may come as a surprise. In fact, according to Lisa M. Lynch of Tufts University and Sandra Black of the New York Federal Reserve, economic Darwinism—the survival of the fittest championed by generations of hard-nosed tycoons—may be doing what legions of organizers could not: putting an end to autocratic bosses and regimented workplaces.

This research shows that the most productive workers are those who are highly motivated, who are in a good relationship with the employer and who are unionised. They are more productive than people in a similar position but who are not unionised.

The relevance of all of that to this annual report is that, if the idea is to encourage good relationships between employer and employee, that is best done—in the sense of being most productive—if done through the unions. The Australian Industrial Relations Commission is a body that is very well placed to introduce into the workplace that proper, happy relationship between the unions and the enterprises. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Order! It being 7.00 p.m., I propose the question:

interjection.para: That the Senate do now adjourn.

talk.start.para: —Earlier today the Senate was told about the corrupt research practices of the Country Liberal Party and the defrauding of Northern Territory taxpayers. The Senate was told that the CLP deliberately misled the Northern Territory Public Service into funding political research under the guidance of the Prime Minister's pollster, Mark Textor, and the current Chief Minister, Shane Stone.

speech.para: I have looked closely at the two reports of the corrupt research by Brian Sweeney and Associates, and I want to highlight the disturbing racial aspects of the methodology and findings. These documents reveal a willingness, even an eagerness, to pit black and white Territorians against each other for political gain—to appeal to the very worst aspects of human nature. The first and most damning fact, the focus group research carried out by Brian Sweeney and Associates and paid for by the Territory government, involved only white participants. A full one-third of the Territory's population was excluded from the survey, surely rendering its conclusions meaningless from the government's standpoint.

According to its title, the report was to be an `Insight into the Northern Territory'—but the findings are based on a survey sample which is chronically unrepresentative. Why then would Mark Textor see fit to exclude the Aboriginal population from the focus groups? The answer is simple: they did not fit the target market. Why would he want to include Aboriginals when they rarely vote CLP and their very presence may have inhibited the ability of his moderators to elicit the types of responses he wanted on the question of race?

Aboriginal issues and the attitudes of the selected `white Territorians' to them appear time and time again through the research report prepared by Ron Klein of Brian Sweeney and Associates. He offers the explanation that, while it was never his intention to focus so extensively on race matters:
Aboriginals emerged in the course of the conversation as a very big issue indeed.

It just sort of happened. How disingenuous is that? This is patent nonsense. For a start, focus groups are not therapy sessions, where participants are given the chance to pontificate on matters of their choice. Moderators are trained to ensure that discussions stay within the ambit of the brief and they would never allow such a wide-ranging diversion.

We also know that Mr Klein's defence of the Aboriginal component of his research—`it was an accident'—can be proven to be false by a letter from Mark Textor to Andrew Coward three years after the research was completed. In this letter to Andrew Coward, Mark Textor advised him on approaches to future research, as follows:

If your interest is to have a Klein style `fresh', `new' view of the political landscape, I would remind you that Klein told us `nothing new' but, for example, put the Aboriginal Issue in its `Two sets of laws' context . . . that sort of finding is a natural outcome of the qualitative research method (where feeling and language is explored in depth).

This tells us three things. Firstly, the material on Aboriginal matters was the direct result of a deliberate line of questioning from the moderator, Klein. Secondly, this methodology was of the sort designed to elicit in-depth emotional responses on race—designed, as Mark Textor explains in the 1993 letter to Coward, to add `flavour' to a political strategy. Thirdly and most revealingly, this letter establishes the connection between the 1994 push polling question and the 1990 research. The notorious `two sets of laws' question resulted directly from this unethically obtained research. And Mark Textor is the common factor.

The report from Brian Sweeney and Associates places a political interpretation on the research findings, which speaks for itself. Consider these words, found on page 33 of the CLP version of the report:
The extent to which the Aboriginal issue is capable of evoking anger should not be underestimated.
If there is any doubt about the vile intent that lies behind those words, it is rammed home unequivocally when Klein later states:
The Aboriginal issue . . . shows the potential to be a major election issue. Handled correctly, we feel the Aboriginal issue could ensure the return of the CLP.
If in politics the price of success is the exploitation of prejudice, then surely that price is too high.

We know, beyond any doubt, that not only was the research in 1990 illegally obtained by the Country Liberal Party but also it was specifically designed to develop a negative race campaign. We know that methodology was employed to elicit emotive responses on race to assist the CLP in maximising their capacity to exploit the issue. We know that, in the eyes of the operatives involved, resentment, intolerance and prejudice is campaign artillery to be ruthlessly exploited in the pursuit of power. We know that behind all of this, at every point in the process, is the man entrusted by the Liberal Party to conduct their research.

The campaign operatives—all still active in Liberal Party politics—engaged in this research with the intention of developing campaign messages to divide the community. In doing so, they excluded the Aboriginal population, preferring instead to limit their research to white swinging voters who would best respond to the race card. They interpreted antagonism toward the Aboriginal community as political manna from heaven and they saw it as the way to election victory.

Our Prime Minister is proud to proclaim his belief that the things that unite us are more enduring than the things that divide us, yet his pollsters and apparatchiks develop campaigns which seek to inflame and exploit division. It should be a matter of very real concern—

talk.start.para: —Madam Acting Deputy President, on a point of order: we are quite happy for Senator Crossin to develop whatever argument she wants, and that is why we have listened to her in silence. But I think that at this point she is getting to the stage where she is going to contravene standing order 193 in that she is now trying to develop an argument which impugns an improper motive to the Prime Minister. What Senator Crossin is trying to do is quite outside the standing orders. I would suggest that you at this stage just warn her that she should not seek to impute improper motives to any member of this chamber or the other but especially to the Prime Minister.

—Madam Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I suggest you not warn Senator Crossin of anything because her speech is totally within the standing orders. I think it is an excellent speech and I for one would like to hear it without interruption by spurious points of order by Senator O'Chee.

—I was in the chair when this debate came on this morning. I am aware of the strong feelings on both sides in this debate. I will listen very closely to what the senator has to say and take into account what Senator O'Chee has raised as a point of order. Senator Crossin, will you please continue?

—I will just repeat, for the sake of the record, the reference to the Prime Minister. You will probably find it is a belief of us all that our Prime Minister is proud to proclaim his belief that the things that unite us are more enduring than the things that divide us. It should though be a matter of very real concern to the Australian people and the Prime Minister that it is Mark Textor, the Prime Minister's own pollster and regular government contractor, who is its foremost practitioner.
—I rise today to speak about the logging of old-growth forests in Western Australia and the impending Regional Forest Agreement.

speech.para: The Regional Forest Agreement public consultation paper has been on the table for some time now, but the battle is far from over. During the RFA review period, some 30,000 submissions were received by the government from concerned Western Australians, and it is to be hoped their concerns will be addressed in the final RFA document. Of those received, an estimated 25,000 submissions directly opposed the logging of the remaining 10 percent of WA's old-growth forests.

In the Western Australian state parliament, the Standing Committee on Ecologically Sustainable Development inquired into the management of, and planning for, the use of state forests in Western Australia. This cross party committee unanimously agreed—that is an important point to note: unanimously agreed—that the Regional Forest Agreement has fallen far short of its intended purpose. There are major discrepancies over the criteria on which the RFA is based. This in turn renders all projections and plans of dubious value. To quote the committee's report:

A pre-requisite for arriving at good solutions about forest use and management, is that figures about existing areas of forest, production forest and reserve forest are available and are accurately and objectively compiled.

This has not been done. The correct data has not been included, which means that the Regional Forest Agreement for Western Australia as proposed is currently based on flawed information. If you add to this the Court government's plan to sign the final agreement without Environmental Protection Authority assessment and with no further public scrutiny, you have a situation of grave concern to me and to hundreds of thousands of Western Australians.

As I speak, a small group of committed conservationists are standing firm in the forests of Wattle Block, near Northcliffe in the south-west of Western Australia—an area listed on the Commonwealth Register of the National Estate. We may see photographs or television footage of these protesters, some with dreadlocks or bare feet, hoisting themselves up into the treetops or chaining themselves to forest machinery, and we may decide we have little in common with these people. But what we must realise is that for every protester in the forest there are thousands and thousands—in fact, hundreds of thousands—of others from what is called `mainstream Australia'—doctors, schoolteachers, lawyers, academics, public servants, truck drivers, scientists, secretaries and gravediggers—mainstream Australians who want the clear-felling of old-growth forests to stop.

You may wonder why I have used the term `hundreds of thousands are opposed'. A survey by AMR Quantum Harris Research conducted earlier this year shows that 87 per cent of Western Australians do not want the timber industry to clear-fell old-growth forests. Eighty-three per cent are opposed to old-growth forests being used for woodchips. That amounts to hundreds of thousands of Western Australians.

Time is running out for our old-growth forests. Every day, hectare upon hectare of jarrah, karri, marri and she-oak trees, many hundreds of years old, are being clear-felled in the south-west of Western Australia.

The Western Australian government must take the utmost care when signing the proposed regional forest agreement. This agreement will determine the future of what little old-growth forest we now have left in Western Australia. Future generations will either applaud them—or despise them—for their actions over the RFA.

On 25 May this year, I rose in this House to speak about a logging coupe known as Dombakup 24. D24 consists of less than 200 hectares of karri, jarrah, she-oak and tingle wood situated some 11 kilometres west of the Northcliffe township in the south-west of our state, and surrounded by private landowners. I remind you that 200 hectares of old-growth forest like that take hundreds of years to grow and would take two weeks to clear-fell.

I am pleased to advise the Senate of a positive outcome for Dombakup 24. Early in 1998, the Department of Conservation and Land Management—whom I have often described as `Genghis CALM' because they are both pillagers and conservers—had earmarked Dombakup 24 for clear-felling but, on 4 August 1998, CALM announced an indefinite moratorium on logging this forest because of its significance to the Aboriginal people.

Unfortunately, CALM had constructed 8½ kilometres of log road through Dombakup 24 before completing the necessary roading checklist. Had that been done, CALM would have discovered the existence of significant Aboriginal places within the forest of Dombakup 24. CALM only needed to contact the Manjimup Aboriginal Corporation to have been told of the significance of that forest to Aboriginal people.

To its credit, CALM acted swiftly when it finally acknowledged the seriousness of its mistake and authorised an archaeological study to be undertaken in the D24 region. That study—by Dortch, Gardos and O'Reilly from the Centre for Archaeology at the University of Western Australia—was conse quently completed and the report was released.

I take this opportunity to applaud CALM for declaring a moratorium on logging at Dombakup 24, but this moratorium should be upgraded from indefinite to permanent. For those 200 hectares, it is a little bit like being on death row. They can at some stage be logged by CALM. I remind the Senate that the Western Australian government have put CALM in the extraordinary situation of being reliant on clear-felling and woodchipping for income for their current expenditure. The result is a massive conflict of interest. The Dortch archaeological report clearly states:
The entire area of Dombakup 24 is highly likely to contain many undisturbed archaeological sites and is archaeologically significant because:
1. It contains the only archaeological sites so far located in Karri tall open forest,
2. These sites are probably the last undisturbed sites associated with Aboriginal exploitation of the Northcliffe Silcrete Quarry, which is an important site in south-western Australia.
The report went on:
Our findings also suggest that the existence of other Aboriginal sites in Karri and other forests is a reasonable proposition.

The events surrounding Dombakup 24 highlight a serious anomaly between the mining and timber industries. Before being granted a mining licence, all prospectors—be they large multinationals or fossickers with metal detectors—are advised that they must comply with the provisions of the Aboriginal Heritage Act before proceeding with excavation of any kind. Those provisions include a search for areas of Aboriginal significance. According to the WA Department of Minerals and Energy:
Damage to a site under the Aboriginal Heritage Act 1990 carries a penalty of up to $10,000 and two years imprisonment.

That is pretty substantial, and the mining industry takes note of it. The fact that CALM, on the other hand, a government agency, undertook to construct log roads right through an area of major significance without having done a search—under their own criteria—of the most basic kind is a matter of serious concern. It must never happen again. If the mining industry can conform to strict guidelines set by the Aboriginal Heritage Act, then so too should CALM and the timber industry. I encourage this Senate to not be sanguine about this RFA process, despite its complexity and the politics that surround it, and really to start to adopt it with the same passion and understanding with which we have adopted other preservation campaigns.

talk.start.para: —Tonight I wish to bring to the Senate's attention a matter of some significance to my state of Tasmania. It is a project to bring HMAS Hobart back to the home port of Hobart. As you well know, Mr Acting Deputy President Sherry, the Royal Australian Navy plan to decommission HMAS Hobart in the year 2000. A specially convened committee of the Naval Association of Australia, Tasmania Section, aim to bring HMAS Hobart from her home port of Sydney, after her decommissioning.

speech.para: The committee plans to acquire the HMAS Hobart and to set up a naval museum and permanent display of HMAS Hobart in the port of Hobart. The committee has a strong interest in preserving Tasmania's naval heritage—indeed it is a rich heritage, Tasmania being an island state—particularly with the declining Royal Australian Navy presence in Hobart.

Apart from the ship being a memorial and museum, the committee envisages the ship as an important tourist facility along the lines of HMAS Castlemaine at Williamstown in Victoria, HMAS Diamantina in Brisbane, and HMAS Vampire at Darling Harbour in Sydney.

It could also be used, if need be, for overnight accommodation, cocktail parties, meetings of specialist small groups. It could be used as a Naval Reserve cadet facility. The options for the siting of the ship vary from tying up alongside, to placing it in a concrete cradle. A concrete cradle is the preferred option.

The committee hopes that HMAS Hobart can be located at one of the wharves in Sullivans Cove or, possibly, near the botanical gardens. The preferred site is at Ross Bay on the Derwent River, just along from the exist ing Naval Reserve cadet facilities and close to the old HMAS Huon naval depot. The ship would be maintained and run by Naval Association volunteers. Planning is certainly in the early stages, but the project involves significant cost implications and will require meticulous long-term planning to succeed. We all wish the project well.

The committee is now seeking public and corporate sponsorship—as well as the cooperation of federal and state politicians and the Hobart City Council. Already, considerable support has been received from the Tasmanian state government and opposition, the Hobart City Council, Tasmanian senators—both Liberal and Labor—Tasmanian members of the House of Representatives, the Hobart Ports Corporation, Admiral Don Chalmers, Chief of Navy, Admiral Mike Hudson, National President of the Naval Association of Australia, the HMAS Hobart Association, the Returned Services League of Australia Inc., Tasmanian Branch, and the Navy League of Australia, Tasmanian Division.

HMAS Hobart is a Charles F. Adams class guided missile destroyer, built by the Defoe Shipbuilding Co. in Michigan in the United States. She is an interesting vessel. She was launched on 9 January 1964 and commissioned on 18 December 1965. In the year of decommissioning—year 2000—she will have been in service for Australia for 35 years.

She has a displacement of 4,500 tons, a length of 437 feet and a beam of 47 feet. She has a speed in excess of 30 knots with a complement of 20 officers and 313 sailors. Her armament includes two 5-inch automatic rapid fire guns, antiaircraft guided missiles, anti-submarine missiles and antisubmarine homing torpedoes.

HMAS Hobart was the first Australian destroyer to be sent to Vietnam, leaving Sydney on 7 March 1967 for attachment to the US Seventh Fleet and returning home for the final time on 11 October 1968. In her first deployment to Vietnam, HMAS Hobart steamed 52,529 miles and came under enemy fire on nine occasions. She fired something like 9,204 rounds at 1,050 targets while in Vietnamese waters. In her second deployment, HMAS Hobart steamed some 44,579 miles and came under fire on three occasions.

Guided missile destroyer ships Perth, Brisbane and Hobart have been so successful that they have continued to be useful well beyond their normal life expectation. They have all been extensively modernised over the years. The primary objective in disposing of any public asset is to maximise the return to the Commonwealth. The Minister for Defence in the first Howard government, the Hon. Ian McLachlan, promised, however, to assess any proposal where it can be demonstrated that substantial benefits will accrue to a local economy by re-utilising an obsolete platform.

Since we are being broadcast, I will take this occasion to pass on to Mr Ian McLachlan, the former Minister for Defence, my sincere sympathy in the recent passing of his father, a distinguished South Australian.

Precedents have been set for the gifting of ships to other states, and the government must give very serious consideration to the gifting of HMAS Hobart to Tasmania. As this class of ship was phased out by the United States navy some years ago, continuing support is difficult and, therefore, removal of some systems and equipment will be required for ongoing support of HMAS Hobart's sister ship, HMAS Brisbane. The committee does, nevertheless, retain the hope that the ship will be as near as possible to her present condition on decommissioning.

The project's goal is significant to the whole of Tasmania—it is certainly advantageous to the city of Hobart—and presents a perfect opportunity to capture significant naval heritage whilst providing a unique state headquarters for the Naval Association in Tasmania.

I therefore take the opportunity afforded by this adjournment debate to urge the new Minister for Defence, the Hon. John Moore, to give favourable consideration to locating the HMAS Hobart in the port of Hobart after her decommissioning in the year 2000. I commend this project to the Senate, and look forward to the support of all senators for this important project.

talk.start.para: —On 14 August 1998, Derek Leon Rees was killed when struck by a train in Richmond. At the time of his death, Derek was about a month short of his 79th birthday. The incident brought to an end the life of a remarkable man.

speech.para: Mr Acting Deputy President, may I send my sympathy to Cynthia, his partner, and his four daughters Diana, Philippa, Biddy and Kim. Derek was born in England on 19 September 1919. In the mid-1930s, when 17 years of age, he came to Australia and began working as a jackaroo. When the Second World War broke out, he enlisted in the Australian Army. He did his duty as a soldier in Palestine, North Africa, India and, later on, the Kokoda Trail. While in New Guinea, he was seriously wounded and thereby affected for the rest of his days. This did not stop his full engagement in life, as all those who knew him can attest.
Derek was a tall man and confident in his stature. Because of his big feet which were attached to a pair of very long legs, he was called `Boots' by all those who knew him well.

A number of his former military comrades attended his funeral and held the customary ceremony at the conclusion of the main service. When Derek left the army in 1946, he joined the Australian Labor Party. In 1949 he left the ALP and joined the Communist Party. This was when the government of the day sent troops into the coal mines. Fortunately, his departure was not a permanent one and he returned to the true faith. He went back to England for some years and worked in England for the ALP while living there. He then returned to Western Australia where he was highly active in the party and served on its state executive. He made many friends there. Senator Evans and Senator McKiernan knew him in the state they both represent so well.

Seven years ago, Derek came to Melbourne to be with Cynthia Mountstephen who was recovering from an operation. She was a longstanding family friend. They both resided at the Old Colonist in North Fitzroy at the time of his death. I would like to quote some words from Cynthia which she spoke after Derek's death. She said:

He was the most loving and generous man, so full of kindness to everybody. I would describe him as charmingly eccentric. I know it sounds ridiculous, because he was nearly 79 and I'm 82, but we had a wonderfully romantic relationship.

While in Melbourne, Derek did an amazing amount of voluntary work. When he died he was the President of the Immigration and Ethnic Affairs Policy Committee of the ALP and I often spoke with him in that context. I had many a discussion with Derek. He came up in conversations I had with others. His reputation was high. He was a selfless man, of joyful disposition, keen to work to the limits of his injured body and dedicated to the causes he espoused.

Derek served Australia in peace and in war, not for reward and status, but because it was in his nature to do so. He is typical of many people who see the interests of others as of fundamental importance and who seek to further them regardless of personal benefit. Their membership of political parties like the ALP gives those parties the best of their spirit and culture. They are the sorts of people who make up the fabric of a good society. Derek was amongst the best of them.
